University of Sheffield, 1994-1999, led by Norman Blake: Michael Pidd and Estelle Stubbs, with Linda Cross, Claire Thomson, Orietta Da Rold and Simon Horobin. In partnership with the Canterbury Tales Project, at that time led by Norman Blake in partnership with Peter Robinson and Elizabeth Solopova (up to 1998), and using images and other resources supplied by the Project, the Sheffield team transcribed eight manuscripts in full (Ad3, Corpus, Dd, Gg, Ellesmere, Ha4, Hengwrt, Lansdowne), sections of some seven other manuscripts, and all manuscripts of the Franklin's Tale. No part of these transcripts is contained in this iteration of the Project.

div.l: Olde ypocras holy and galyene
Serapion rasi and auysene
Auaroys damascien and constantyn
Bernard gattisdene and gylbertyn
Of his diete mesurable was he
For it was of no superfluyte
But of grete norsyngꝭes and digestible
His study was but litill in the bible
Of sanguyn and of pers his clothingꝭes alle
Lyned with taffada and sendall
And yit he was but esy in dispence
He kepte that he wanne in pestelence
For golde in phisik is a cordiall
Therefore he loued golde in speciall
A gode wife there was of bathe
But she was defe and þat was scathe
Of clothe makingꝭes had she suche an haunte
She passid hem of ypres and of gaunte
In alle þe ꝑper/parisshe was Ther wife none
Þat to the offeryngꝭes before here wolde gone
And yif þere dede certein wrothe was she
That sche was oute of alle charite
Hire keủer/rechiefs full fyne were of grounde
I durst suere thei weyed . x . b .
That on a sonday was on here hede
Hire hose were of fine scarlet rede
Full straite teide and shoes full newe
Bolde was hire face and rudy and faire of hewe
She was a worthi woman alle here life
Husbondes atte chirche dore hadde she fyue
With oute other Cumpany in youthe
But there of nedeth not to speke as nowth
iij had sche be atte Ierlm
She hadde passid many a stronge streme
Catte tothid she was sothely to say
Sche couthe moche of wanderyngꝭes be the way
Vppon an ambler esely she sate
Wympled well and on here hede an hatte
As brode as is abokeler or a targe
A fote mantell aboute hir hippes large
And on hure fete a peire of spures sharpe
In felawshipp well cowde sche laughe and carpe
Of remedys of loue she couthe ꝑper/parchauns
For she couthe of that arte the dauns
A gode man was there of religiou
And was apore ꝑper/parsoun of a toun
But riche was he of holy werke
He was a lerned man a clerke
That Cristes gospell truly wolde preche
His parisshens devoutely wolde teche
Benygne he was and wonder diligent
And in aduersite full pacient
And suche he was ꝓproued ofte sithes
Full lothe were him to curs for his tithes
But radder wolde he gefe oute of doute
To his pore parisshens aboute
Of his offeryngꝭes and of his substaunce
He couth in litill þingꝭes haue sustinaunce
Wide was his ꝑper/parissh and houses ferre a sonder
But he lefte not for reyne ne for þonder
In sikenes or in mischief to visite
The ferrest of his ꝑper/parisshe moche and lyte
Vppon his fete and in his honde a staffe
This noble ensaumple to his shepe he gaffe
That firste he wrought and aftirward he taght
Oute of the gospell the wordes he caught
And this figure he addid eke there to
That yif golde ruste what shulde Iren do
For yif a preste be foull on wham we truste
No wonder ys a lewde man to ruste
And shame it is yif a preste take kepe
A schetten shiphard and a clene shepe
Wel aght a preste ensaumple for to gyue
Be his clawses howe that his shepe shulde leue
He sette not his benefice to hire
And lette his schepe be combrid in the myre
And ryn to londou to seint poules
To seche hym a chauntre for soules
Or with a Bretherhede to halde
But duellid atte home and kepte well his falde
So that the wolfe had it not to miscary
He was a shiphard and not a mercenary
And though he holy were and vertuous
He was not to sinfull men dispitous
Nor of his speche dangerous and digne
But in his speche discrete and benigne
To drawe folke to heuene be fairenes
Be gode ensaumple this was his besines
But it were any persoun abstinate
Who so he were of hie and lowe estate
Hym wolde he snyb sharpely for þe nones
A bett̉er/re preste I trowe non wher is
He waites after no pompe nor reủer/reens
Nor he made him not a spicid contenaunce
But cristes lore and his apostels xij
He tought but firste he folwid it him selfe
With him there was a ploghman his oune brother
That had lad of donge many a fother
A trewe swynker and a gode was he
Leuyngꝭes in peas and in charite
God loued he beste with all his herte
Atte alle tyme thogh him gamed or smerte
And than his neigheboᵘur as him selfe
He wolde thressh and ther to dike and dewe
For cristis sake to eủer/rey pore wight
With oute hire yif it lay in his myght
His tithes paide he full faire and wele
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke and of his catele
In a tabarde he rode vp on a mere
There was also a ryve and a Millere
A sompnoᵘur and a ꝑper/pardoner also
A mansiple and my selfe there was nomo
The Miller was a stoute chorle for the nones
Full bygge he was of brawne and of bones
That ꝓproves well for oủer/re alle that wher he came
Atte werstelyngꝭes he wolde haue the game
He was schort shuldrid and thicke knarre
Ther was no dore þat he wolde haue an harre
Well wyste he be the drought and be the reyne
The yeldingꝭes of his sede and of his greyne
His lordes nete his shepe his dayery
His somer his hors his store and his pultry
Was holy in the reues goủer/renyngꝭes
And by his couenaunt yaue rekenyngꝭes
Sothe his lorde was xxᵗⁱ yere of age
Ther couthe noman bringꝭes him in rerage
There nas baillif herde nor other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleight and his couyne
Thei were adrad of him as for the dethe
His wonnyngꝭes was full faire vp on an hethe
With grene trees shadowid was his place
He couth bett̉er/re than his lorde purchace
Full riche he was astorid full priuely
His lorde he couth plese skilfully
To lenne and gyfe hym of his oune gode
And haue a thanke and ȝit a cote and a hode
In youthe he had lerned a gode myster
He was a gode wright a Carpent̉er/re
This reue sate vpon a well gode stotte
That was pomely gray and heght scotte
A longꝭes surcote of ypres vpon he hadde
And be his side he bare alusty blade
Of Norfolk was the reue of wheche I tell
Beside a toun that hite Baldeswell
Tukkid he was as a frere aboute
And eủer/re he rode hynmost of oure route
A Somenour was with vs in þat place
That had a faire rede cherubyns face
For sawcefleme he was with eien narrowe
And hote he was and lecherous as a sparowe
With scallid browes blak and pillid berde
Of his visage children was a ferde
Ther nas quik silver litarge ne brymston
Boras ceruse ne oyle of tarter none
Nore vnyment that wolde clanse and bite
That him might helpe of his whelkis white
Nor of the clobbes sittyngꝭes on his chekes
Well loued he garlik vneons and lekes
And for to drinke stronge wyne as blode
Thanne wolde he slepe and crie as he were wode
And whanne he had well dronken the wyne
Than nolde he speke no worde but latyne
A fewe termes had he ij or iij
That he had lerned oute of sum degre
No wonder is he herde it alle þe day
And eke ye knowe well that a Iay
Can clepe wat as well as the pope
But who couthe him in other thingꝭes grope
Than had he spente alle his philosophie
A questio que iuris wolde he crie
He was a gentill harlot and a kynde
A bett̉er/re fellowe shulde no man fynde
He wolde suffre for a quarte of wyn
A gode fellowe to haue his concubyn
A tuelmonth and excuse him atte full
And priuely a fyn eke couth he pull
And yif he fonde any gode felawe
He wolde teche him to haue non awe
In suche case of the Archedekens cours
But yif mannes soule were in his purs
For in his purs shuld he ponyste be
The purs is the Archedekens hell qd he
But well I wote he leide in dede
Of cursyngꝭes aght yche man to haue drede
For cursyngꝭes sleith right as asoillyngꝭes saueth
And also be warre him of a significauit
In danger hadde he atte his oune gise
The yonge girles of the diocise
And knewe hire counsell and was here rede
A garland had he vp on his heued
As grete as it were for an Ale stake
A Bukeler had he made hym of a cake
With him ther rode a gentill ꝑper/pardoner
Of Rouncevale his frende and his comper
That streight was come from the courte of Rome
Full loude he sange come hidder loue to me haue done
This sompnour bare with him a stiffe burdoun
Was neủer/re trompe of halfe so grete a soun
This ꝑper/pardoner had hare as ȝalowe as fflex wex
Smothe it was and hange as Flex
Be vnces hange his lockes that he hadde
And there with he his shuldres ouer spradde
But thyn it lay be culpons one and one
But hoode for Iolyte wered he none
For it was trussid vp in his walet
Him thoght he rode alle of the newe get
Discheuele safe his cappe he rode al bare
Suche glaryngꝭes eien had he as an hare
A vernacle had he sowed on his cappe
His walet before hym in his lappe
Bratfull of ꝑper/pardou that come from Rome alle hote
A voice he had as smale as hathe a gote
No berde hadde he nor neủer/re shuld haue
As smothe it was as it were newe y schaue
I trowe he were a gildyngꝭes or a mare
But of his Crafte from Berwyk vn to ware
Ne was there suche a pardonere
From his male he had a pillowe bere
Wheche he saide was ouer laide wele
He saide he had eke a gobet of the sele
That seint petir hadde whan þat he wente
Vppon the see till Ihıı̄un criste hym hente
He hadde of crosse of latou full of stones
And in a glas he hadde pygges bones
But with thes relykes whan that he fonde
A pore ꝑper/parsou dwellingꝭes vp on londe
Vp on a day he gate him more money
Then the ꝑper/parsou gate in mounthes twey
And thus with feyned flatry and fapes
He made the ꝑper/parsou and the peple his apes
But trewely to telle atte laste
He was in chirche a noble eccleciaste
Well couth he rede A lesou or a story
But aldeste he sangꝭes an Offratory
For well he wyste whan that was songe
He moste preche and well afyle his tonge
To wyn silver as he well cowde
Therefore he sangꝭes the meuell cowde
Howe haue I tolde you sothely in a clause
The state the aray the nombre ⁊and the cause
Whi that assemblid was this Cumpany
In suthwerk atte this gentill hostery
That heght the tabt faste be the bell
But nowe is tyme yow for to tell
Howe that we bare vs the same nyght
Whan we were in that ostry a right
And after will I telle of oure viage
And alle the remanent of oure pilgrimage
And firste I pray you for youre curtasy
That ȝe directe it not my vilany
Thogh I pleynly speke in this matere
And tell you her wordes and her chere
And thowe I speke here wordes ꝓpropirly
For this ye knowe as well as y
Who shall telle a tale after a man
He moste rehers as ney as euer he can
Criste spake him self full brode in holy writte
And well ye wote no vilany is it
Eke plato seith who can hym rede
The worde moste be cusyn to the dede
Also I pᵃy you for ȝife it me
All thof I haue not sette folke in her degre
Here in thes tales as thei shulde stonde
My witte is shorte ye may well vnderstonde .
Grete chere made oure oste to vs eủer/reychon
And to sopere he sette vs and that anon
He seruid vs with vitaill atte beste
Stronge was the wyne and well to drinke vs liste
A semelich man oure hoste was with alle
For to haue ben an vssher of an halle
A large man was he with yen stepe
A fairer burgeis was none in chepe
Bolde of his speche ⁊and wis ⁊and well y taught
And of manhode lackid him right noght
Eke there to he was a mery man
And aft̉er/re soper to pley he began
And spake of myrthe amonges otherþinges
Whan þat we had made oure rekenynges
And saide þus lordyngꝭes trewly
Ye ben welcome to me hertely
For be my trowthe yf that I shulde not lie
I ne sawe this yere so mery a companye
Atte onys in this herberowe as is nowe
Fayne wolde I do you myrthe wiste I howe
And of mirthe I am right well be thought
To do you ese and it shall coste you not
Ye gone to Caunterbury god you spede
The blisfull martir quyte youre mede
And well I wote as ye go by þe way
Ye shapen yow to talken and play
For trewly comforte ne myrth is none
To ride be the way as dome as stone
And therefore will I make you sum disporte
As I saide erste and do you some comforte
And yif you likith alle be one assente
For to stonde atte my Iugement
And for to werche right as I shall saye
To morwe whan ye riden be the waye
Nowe be my fadres soule that is dede
But yf ye be mery I gyue you myn hede
Holde vp youre hondes with oute more speche
Oure counsaill was not longe to seche
We thought not to make it wys
And grauntid him with oute more avys
And badde hym sey his verdite as hym liste
Lordyngꝭes qd he nowe herkeneth the beste
But takith it not I pray you in disdayne
This is the poynte to speke shorte and playne
That eủer/reyche of you to shorte his weye
In this viage shall telle tales tweye
To Caunterbury wardes I mene it so
And homewardes he shalle telle other two
Of Auentours that whilom hath bifalle
And wheche of you berith him beste of alle
That is to say telleth in this caas
Tales of beste sentence and solas
Shall haue a soper atte oure alther coste
Here in this place sittyngꝭes atte this poste
Whanne that we come agayn from Caunt̉er/rebury
And for to make you the more mery
I wille my selfe gladliche with you ride
Atte myn oune coste and be youre gide
And who so will my Iugement denye
Shall paye alle that we spende be the waye
And ye vouchesaufe that it be so
Telle me anone with oute wordes mo
And I will erely shape me there fore
Thes thyngꝭes was grauntid ⁊and othes swore
With full glad herte and praide hym also
That he wolde vouchesafe so to do
And that he wolde be oure gouernoure
And of oure tales Iuge and reportoure
And set a suꝑper/par atte a certein price
And we wolde rewlid be atte his devyce
In high and lowe ⁊and þus be one assente
We ben accordid to his Iugemente
And there vp on the wyne was fette anone
We dranke and to reste wente eche one
With oute any lenger taryingꝭes
On the morue whan the day gan springe
Vp rose oure oste that was oure kok
And gadrid vs to gedre in a flok
And forthe we reden litil more þan pace
Vn to the wateryngꝭes of seint Thomas
And ther oure oste began his hors arreste
And saide sires herkenith yif you liste
I wote your forwarde ⁊and I shall you recorde
Yf mornsongꝭes and euesongꝭes accorde
Late se nowe who shall tell firste his tale
As euer mote I drinke wyn or ale
Who so be rebell to my Iugement
Shall paie for alle that be the wai y spente
Nowe drawe cutte or we further twyn
He wheche hathe the shortest shall be gyn
Sire knyght qd he my Maister and lorde
Nowe drawith Cut for that is myn accorde
Cometh nere qd he my lady prioresse
And ye sire clerke let be youre shamefastnes
Ne studieth not lay honde on eủer/rey man
And anone to drawe iche wight be gan
And schortely to tell as it was
Were it be auenture sort or cas
The suth is the Cut fel to the knyght
Of wheche ful glad was eủer/rey wight
And tell moste his tale as resoun was
Be forward and composicou
As ye haue herde what nedith wordis moo
And whanne this gode manne sawe that it was so
As he that wis was and obedient
Toke his forwarde be his owne assent
He saide sethens I shall begynne the game
Welcome be the Cut in goddis name
Nowe late vs ride and herkeneth what I say
And with that worde we ryden forthe oure way

(base) Iamque domos patria Scithice post asꝑper/para gentis laurigero etc Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
(base) Whilom / as olde stories tellen vs
(base) Ther was a Duc that highte Theseus
(base) Of Atthenes / he was lord and gouernour
(base) And in his tyme / swich a conquerour
(base) That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
(base) Ful many a riche contree / hadde he wonne
(base) What with his wysdom / and his chiualrye
(base) He conquered / al the regne of femenye
(base) That whilom / was ycleped Scithia
(base) And wedded / the queene ypolita

div.l: (base) And broghte hire hom with hym / in his contree
(base) With muchel glorie / and greet solempnitee
(base) And eek / hir yonge suster Emelye
(base) And thus with victorie / and with melodye
(base) Lete I this noble Duc to Atthenes ryde
(base) And al his hoost . in armes hym bisyde
(base) ¶ And certes / if it nere to long to heere
(base) I wolde haue toold / fully the manere
(base) How / wonnen was the regne of Femenye
(base) By Theseus / and by his Chiualrye
(base) And of the grete bataille / for the nones
(base) Bitwixen Atthenes / and Amazones
(base) And how assegeged was ypolita
(base) The faire hardy queene of Scithia
(base) And of the feste / that was at hir weddynge
(base) And of the tempest at hir hom comynge
(base) But al that thyng I moot as now forbere
(base) I haue god woot a large feeld to ere
(base) And wayke / been the oxen in my plogh
(base) The remenant of the tale / is long ynogh
(base) I wol nat letten eek / noon of this route
(base) Lat euery felawe / telle his tale aboute
(base) And lat se now / who shal the souper wynne
(base) And ther I lefte / I wol ayein bigynne
(base) Incipit narracio
(base) ¶ Here bygynneth the knyghtes tale.
(base) This duc of whom I make mencioun
(base) Whanne he was come / almoost to the town
(base) In al his wele / and in his mooste pryde
(base) He was war / as he caste his eye asyde
(base) Wher that ther kneled / in the heighe weye
(base) A compaignye of ladyes / tweye and tweye
(base) Ech after /oother clad in clothes blake
(base) But swich a cry / and swich a wo they make
(base) That in this world / nys creature lyuynge
(base) That herde / swich another waymentynge
(base) And of this cry / they nolde neuere stenten
(base) Til they / the reynes of his brydel henten
(base) ¶ What folk been ye / that at myn hom comynge
(base) Perturben so my feste / with cryynge
(base) Quod Theseus / haue ye so greet envie
(base) Of myn honour / that thus compleyne and crye
(base) Or who hath yow mysboden / or offended
(base) And telleth me / if it may been amended
(base) And why that ye / been clothed thus in blak /
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
(base) Dooth to the ladys / whan they from hym wente
(base) But shortly / for to telle is myn entente
(base) ¶ Whan that this worthy duc this Theseus
(base) Hath Creoun slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
(base) Stille in that feeld / he took al nyght his reste
(base) And dide withal the contree / as hym leste
(base) ¶ To ransake in the taas / of bodies dede
(base) Hem for to strepe / of harneys / and of wede
(base) The pilours / diden bisynesse / and cure
(base) After the bataille / and disconfiture
(base) And so bifel / in the taas they founde
(base) Thurgh girt with many a greuous blody wownde
(base) Two yonge knyghtes / liggynge by and by
(base) Bothe in oon armes / wroght ful richely
(base) Of whiche two / Arcita highte that oon
(base) And that oother knyght highte Palamon
(base) Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they weere
(base) But by hir Cote armures / and by hir geere
(base) The heraudes / knewe hem best in special
(base) As they that weren / of the blood roial
(base) Of Thebes / and of sustren two yborn
(base) Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
(base) And han hem caryed / softe vnto the tente
(base) Of Theseus / and he ful soone hem sente
(base) To Atthenes / to dwellen in prisoun
(base) Perpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy duc / hath thus ydoon
(base) He took his oost / and hom he ryt anoon
(base) With laurer corouned / as a conquerour
(base) And there he lyueth / in ioye / and in honour
(base) Terme of his lyf / what nedeth wordes mo
(base) And in a tour / in angwissh and in wo
(base) Dwellen this Palamon / and eek Arcite
(base) For euere moore / ther may no gold hem quyte
(base) ¶ This passeth yeer by yeer / and day by day
(base) Til it fil ones / in a morwe of May

(base) Yclenched / ouerthwart and endelong /
(base) With Iren togh / and for to make it strong
(base) Euery piler / the temple to sustene
(base) Was tonne greet of Iren bright and shene
(base) ¶ Ther say I first. the dirke ymagynynge
(base) Of felonye / and al the compassynge
(base) The cruel Ire / reed as any gleede
(base) The pike purs / and eek the pale drede
(base) The smylere / with the knyf vnder the cloke
(base) The shipne brennyng with the blake smoke
(base) The tresoun / of the mordryng in the bed
(base) The open werre / with woundes al bibled
(base) Contek with blody knyf and sharp manace
(base) Al ful of chirkyng was that sory place
(base) ¶ The sleere of hymself / yet saugh I ther
(base) His herte blood / hath bathed al his heer
(base) The nayl ydryuen / in the shode a nyght
(base) The colde deeth / with mouth gapyng vp right
(base) Amyddes of the temple / sat meschaunce
(base) With disconfort and sory contenaunce
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I woodnesse / laughyng in his rage
(base) Armed compleynt out hees / and fiers outrage
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) The caroyne in the bussh / with throte ycorue
(base) A thousand slayn / and noght of qualm ystorue
(base) The tiraunt with the praye / by force yraft
(base) The town destroyed / ther was no thyng laft
(base) ¶ Yet saugh I brent. the shippes hoppesteres
(base) The hunte strangled / with the wilde beres
(base) The hunt strangled with wilde bores corage
(base) The Sowe freten the child / right in the Cradel
(base) The Cook yscalded / for al his longe ladel
(base) ¶ Naught was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
(base) The Cartere / ouer ryden / with his Carte
(base) Vnder the wheel / ful lowe he lay adown
(base) Ther were also / of Martes deuysioun
(base) The Barbour / and the Bochier and the Smyth
(base) That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his styth
(base) ¶ And al aboue / depeynted in a tour
(base) Saugh I Conquest sittyng in greet honour
(base) With the sharpe swerd / ouer his heed
(base) Hangynge / by a subtil twynes threed
(base) ¶ Depeynted was / the slaghtre of Iulius
(base) Of grete Nero / and of Anthonius
(base) Al be / that thilke tyme / they were vnborn
(base) Yet was hir deeth / depeynted ther biforn
(base) By manacynge of Mars / right by figure
(base) So was it shewed / in that purtreyture
(base) As is depeynted / in the Sertres aboue
(base) Who shal be slayn / or ellis deed for loue
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample / in stories olde
(base) I may nat rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
(base) ¶ The Statue of Mars / vpon a Carte stood
(base) Lyke vnto the figure of vigynys
(base) Armed / and loked grym / as he were wood
(base) And ouer his heed / ther shynen two figures
(base) Of sterres / that been clepyd in Scriptures
(base) That oon Puella / that oother Rubeus
(base) This god of armes / was arrayed thus
(base) A wolf ther stood / bifore hym at his feet
(base) With eyen rede / and of a man he eet
(base) With subtil pencel / was depeynted this storie
(base) In redoutynge of Mars / and of his glorie
(base) ¶ Now to the temple / of Diane the chaste
(base) As shortly as I kan / I wol me haste
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) To telle yow / al the discripsioun
(base) Depeynted been the walles / vp and doun
(base) Of huntyng and of shamefast chastitee
(base) Ther saw I. / how woful Calistopee
(base) Whan that Diane / agreued was with here
(base) Was turned / fro a womman / til a Bere
(base) And after was she maad / the lode sterre
(base) Thus was it peynted / I kan seye yow no ferre
(base) That shynyth in the hevy / frōm yow so ferre
(base) Hir sone is eek a sterre / as men may see
(base) Ther saw I Dane / yturned to a tree
(base) I mene nat / the goddesse Diane
(base) But Penneus doghter / which that highte Dane
(base) ¶ Ther saw I Attheon / an hert ymaked
(base) For vengeaunce / that he saw Diane al naked
(base) I seigh / how that hise houndes haue hym caught
(base) And freten hym / for that they knewe hym naught
(base) ¶ Yet peynted was / a litel ferther moor
(base) How Atthalante / hunted the wilde boor
(base) And Meleagree / and many another mo
(base) For which Diane / wroghte hym care and wo
(base) Ther saw I. many another wonder storie
(base) The whiche / me list nat drawen to memorie
(base) ¶ This goddesse on hert ful hye seet
(base) With smale houndes / al aboute hir feet
(base) And vnder nethe hir feet. she hadde a moone
(base) Wexinge it was / and sholde wanye soone
(base) In gaude grene / hir statue yclothed was
(base) With bowe in honde / and arwes in a cas
(base) Hir eyen caste she / ful lowe adown
(base) Ther Pluto / hath his dirke Regioun
(base) A womman trauailyng was hir biforn
(base) But for hir child / so longe was vnborn
(base) Ful pitously / lucina gan she calle
(base) And seyde help / for thow mayst best of alle
(base) Wel koude he peynte lyfly / that it wroghte
(base) With many a floryn / he the hewes boghte
(base) ¶ Now been thise listes maad / and Theseus
(base) That at his grete cost arrayed thus
(base) The temples / and the Theatre euery del
(base) Whan it was doon / hym liked wonder wel
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) But stynte I wole / of Theseus alite
(base) And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
(base) ¶ The day approcheth / of hir retournynge
(base) That euerich / sholde an hundred knyghtes brynge
(base) The bataille to darreyne / as I yow tolde
(base) And til Atthenes / hir couenant for to holde
(base) Hath euerich of hem / broght a hundred knyghtes
(base) Wel armed for the werre / at alle rightes
(base) And sikerly / ther trowed many a man
(base) That neuere sithen / that the world bigan
(base) As for to speke / of knyghthod of hir hond
(base) As fer / as god hath maked see and lond
(base) Nas of so fewe / so noble a compaignye
(base) For euery wight that loued chiualrye
(base) And wolde his thankes / han a passant name
(base) Hath prayd / that he myghte been of that game
(base) And wel was hym / that ther to chosen was
(base) For if ther fille / tomorwe swich a cas
(base) Ye knowen wel / that euery lusty knyght /
(base) That loueth paramours / and hath his myght
(base) Were it in Engelond / or ellis where
(base) They wolde hir thankes / wilnen to be there
(base) To fighten for a lady / benedicitee
(base) It were a lusty sighte / for to see
(base) ¶ And right so / ferden they with Palamon
(base) With hym ther wenten / knyghtes many oon
(base) Som wol ben armed / in an haubergeoun
(base) And in a Brestplate / and in a light gypoun
(base) And som wol haue / a peire plates large
(base) And some willen haue a pruce schelde othir targe
(base) And som wol haue / a Pruce sheeld / or a targe
(base) Som wol been armed / on his legges weel
(base) And haue an Ax / and som a Maas of steel
(base) Ther nys no newe gyse / that it nas oold
(base) Armed were they / as I haue yow toold
(base) Euerich / after his opinyoun
(base) ¶ Ther maystow seen / comynge with Palamoun
(base) Lygurge hymself the grete kyng of Trace
(base) Blak was his beerd / and manly was his face
(base) The cercles of his eyen / in his heed
(base) They gloweden / bitwixen yelow and reed
(base) And lyk a griffoun / loked he aboute
(base) With keempe herys / on his browes stoute
(base) His lymes grete / his brawnes / harde and stronge
(base) Hys shuldres brode / hise armes rounde and longe
(base) And as the gyse was / in his contree
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Ne how the Grekys / with An huge route
(base) Thries ryden / al the fyr aboute
(base) Vpon the left hand / with a loud shoutynge
(base) And thries / with hir speres claterynge
(base) And thryes wᵗith here sperys claterynge
(base) And thries / how the ladyes gonne crye
(base) And how that lad / was homward Emelye
(base) Ne how Arcite / is brent to Asshen colde
(base) Ne how that lychwake / was yholde
(base) Al thilke nyght ne how the grekys pleye
(base) The wake pleyes / ne kepe I noght to seye
(base) Who wrastleth best naked / with oille enoynt
(base) Ne who that baar hym best in no disioynt
(base) I wol nat tellen al / how they goon
(base) Hoom til Atthenes / whan the pleye is doon
(base) But shortly to the poynt than wol I wende
(base) And maken / of my longe tale an ende
(base) ¶ By proces / and by lengthe of certeyn yerys
(base) Al stynt is / the moornynge and the terys
(base) Of Grekys / by oon general assent
(base) Thanne semed me / ther was a parlement
(base) At Atthenes / vpon a certeyn point and caas
(base) Among the whiche pointes / yspoken was
(base) To haue / with certeyn contrees alliance
(base) And haue fully / of Thebans obeisance
(base) For which / this noble Theseus anon
(base) Leet senden / after gentil Palamon
(base) Vnwist of hym / what was the cause and why
(base) But in his blake clothes / sorwefully
(base) He cam at his comandement / in hye
(base) Tho sente Theseus / for Emelye
(base) ¶ Whan they were set and hust was al the place
(base) And Theseus / abiden hath a space
(base) Er any word / cam from his wise brest /
(base) His eyen sette he / ther as was his lest
(base) And with a sad visage / he siked stille
(base) And after that right thus he seyde his wille
(base) ¶ The firste moeuere / of the cause aboue
(base) Whan he first made / the faire cheyne of loue
(base) Greet was theffect and heigh was his entente
(base) Wel wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
(base) For with that faire cheyne of loue he boond
(base) The fyr the Eyr / the water / and the loond
(base) In certeyn boundes / that they may nat flee
(base) That same Prince / and that moeuere quod he
(base) Hath stabliced / in this wrecched world adoun
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Certeine dayes / and duracioun
(base) To al / that is engendred / in this place
(base) Ouer the which day / they may nat pace
(base) Al mowe they yet / tho dayes abregge
(base) Ther nedeth / noon auctoritee to allegge
(base) For it is proued / by experience
(base) But that me list declaren my sentence
(base) Thanne may men wel / by this ordre discerne
(base) That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
(base) Wel may men knowe / but it be a fool
(base) That euery part. is diryued from his hool
(base) For nature / hath nat taken his bigynnyng
(base) Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
(base) But of a thyng. that parfit is and stable
(base) Descendynge so / til it be corrumpable
(base) And therfore / for his wise purueiaunce
(base) He hath / so wel biset his ordinaunce
(base) That specis of thynges / and progressions
(base) Shullen enduren / by successions
(base) And noght eterne / withouten any lye
(base) This maist thow vnderstonde / and seen at Iye
(base) ¶ Loo the ook / that hath so long a norisshynge
(base) Fro the tyme / that it first gynneth sprynge
(base) And hath so long a lyf / as ye may see
(base) Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
(base) ¶ Considreth eek / how that the harde stoon
(base) Vnder oure foot on which we ryde and goon
(base) It wasteth / as it lyth by the weye
(base) The brode Ryuer / som tyme wexeth dreye
(base) The grete townes / se we wane and wende
(base) Thanne se ye / that al this thyng hath ende
(base) Of man and womman / se we wel also
(base) That nedeth / in oon of thise termes two
(base) This is to seyn / in youthe / or ellis age
(base) He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
(base) Som in his bed / som in the depe see
(base) Som in the large feeld / as ye may se
(base) Ther helpeth noght al gooth that ilke weye
(base) Thanne may I seyn / that al this thyng moot deye
(base) What maketh this but Iuppiter the kyng
(base) That is Prince / and cause of alle thyng
(base) Conuertyng al vnto his propre welle
(base) From which it is diryued sooth to telle
(base) And heer agayns / no creature on lyue
(base) Of no degree / auailleth for to stryue
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) ¶ Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me
(base) To maken vertu / of necessitee
(base) And take it wel / that we may nat eschue
(base) And nameliche / that to vs alle is due
(base) And who so gruccheth oght he dooth folye
(base) And rebel is / to hym that al may gye
(base) And certeinly / a man hath moost honour
(base) To dyen / in his excellence and flour
(base) Whan he is siker / of his goode name
(base) Thanne hath he doon / his freend ne hym no shame
(base) And gladder oghte / his freend been of his deeth
(base) Whan with honour / yolden is vp his breeth
(base) Than whan his name / apalled is for age
(base) For al forgeten is his vasselage
(base) Thanne is it best as for a worthy fame
(base) To dyen / whan he is best of name
(base) ¶ The contrarie of al this / is wilfulnesse
(base) Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
(base) That goode Arcite / of chiualrie flour
(base) Departed is / with duetee / and with honour
(base) Out of this foule prison / of this lyf
(base) Why gruccheth heere / his cosyn and his wyf /
(base) Of his welfare / that loueth hem so weel
(base) Kan he hem thank nay god woot neuer a deel
(base) That bothe his soule / and eek hem self offende
(base) And yet they mowe / hir lustes nat amende
(base) ¶ What may I conclude / of this longe serye
(base) But after wo / I rede vs to be merye
(base) And thanken Iuppiter / of al his grace
(base) And er we / departen from this place
(base) I rede we make / of sorwes two
(base) O parfit Ioye / lastynge euere mo
(base) And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is her Inne
(base) Ther wol I first amenden and bigynne
(base) ¶ Suster quod he / this is my ful assent
(base) With al thauys / heer of my parlement
(base) That gentil Palamon / youre owene knyght
(base) That serueth yow / with wyl and herte myght
(base) And euere hath doon / syn ye first hym knewe
(base) That ye shal of youre grace vpon hym rewe
(base) And taken hym / for housbond and for lord
(base) Leen me youre hond / for this is oure acord
(base) Lat se now / of youre wommanly pitee
(base) He is / a kynges brother sone pardee
(base) And thogh he were / a poure Bachiler
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yeer
(base) And had for yow / so greet aduersitee
(base) It moste been considred / leueth me
(base) For gentil mercy / oghte to passen right
(base) ¶ Thanne seyde he thus / to Palamon the knyght
(base) I trowe / ther nedeth litel sermonyng
(base) To make yow / assente to this thyng
(base) Com neer / and taketh youre lady by the hond
(base) Bitwixe hem / was maad anon the bond
(base) That highte matrymoigne / or mariage
(base) By al the conseil / and the Baronage
(base) And thus / with alle blisse / and melodye
(base) Hath Palamon / ywedded Emelye
(base) And god / that al this world hath wroght
(base) Sende hym his loue / that hath it deere aboght
(base) For now is Palamon / in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blisse / in richesse / and in heele
(base) And Emelye / hym loueth so tendrely
(base) And he / hir serueth so gentilly
(base) That was ther no word hem bitwene
(base) Of Ialousie / or any oother teene
(base) Thus endeth Palamon / and Emelye
(base) And god saue / al this faire compaignye Amen
(base) ¶ Here is ended / the knyghtes tale
¶ ꝓprolog of the miller
When that the knyght had thus his tale y tolde
In alle the rowte nas ther yonge ne olde
But he saide it was a nobill storye
And worthy to be drawe in memorie
And nameliche þe gentils eủer/reychone
Oure hoste lough and swore so mote I gone
Þis gothe aright vnboclid is the male
Lette se nowe who shall telle another tale
For trewly the game is well begunne
Nowe telleth ʆser/sir monke yf that ye konne
Some what to quite with the knyghtꝭes tale
Þe Miller that for druncken was of ale
So that vnneth vppon his hors he sate
He nolde availl neiþ̉er/re hoode ne hatte
Ne abide noman for his curtesie
But in pilate voice he began to crie
And sware by armes blode and bones
I can a noble tale for the nones
With whiche I will nowe quite þe kynges tale
Oure hoste sawe that he was dronken of ale
And saide abide Robyn abide leue brother
Some bett̉er/re man shall tell vs firste a nother
Hir forhede shone as bright as eny day
So was it wasshe when she lefte hir werke
Nowe was there of the chirche a ꝑper/parisshe clerke
Þe wheche was clepid Absolou
Crull was his hede and as þe golde it shone
And stroutid as a fan large and brode
Full streight and euene lay his shode
His rode was rede his eyen gray as goos
With powles wyndowes corue on his shoes
In hosen rede he wente fetesly
Y clad he was full small and ꝓpropirly
All in a kirtill of light waget
Full faire and thikke ben the pointes sette
And there vp on he had a gay surplice
As white as is the blossom on ryse
A mery childe he was so god me saue
Wel coude he lete blode clippe and shaue
And make a chartre of londe or acquitaunce
In xxᵗⁱ maners he couth trippe and daunce
Aft̉er/re the Scole of Oxenford tho
And with his leggꝭes castingꝭes to and fro
And pley songes on a smale rebibe
Some time he songe a loude quynyble
And as well couthe he pley on a Gitterne
In alle the toune nas brewehous ne Tauerne
But he ne wist with his solace
Þer any gaylard Tapster was
But sothe to sey he was sum dele Squaymous
Of Fartingꝭes and of speche dangerous
This Absolou that was Ioly and gay
Goþ with a censure on the sonday
Sensyngꝭes the wives of the ꝑper/parisshe faste
And many a louely loke on hem he caste
And namely on the Carpenters wife
To loke on hir him thoght a mery life
So was so ꝓpropre and swete and likerous
I dar well sey and she had be a mous
And he a catte he wolde her hente anone
This ꝑper/parissh clerk thes Ioly Absolou
Hathe in his herte suche a loue longingꝭes
Þat of no wife toke he none offeringꝭes
For curtasie he saide he wolde none
The mone whanne it was night bright shone
And Absolou his gytterne hathe I take
For ꝑper/paramours he thought to wake ¶
And forthe he gothe gelous and amerous
Till he come to the Carpent̉er/res hous
A litill after the cok had I crowe
And dressid him vnder a shitte wyndowe
Þat was vppon þe Carpenters walle
He singith in his vois gentill and small
Nowe dere lady yif thi will be
I pray you that ye will rewe on me
Full well accordingꝭes to his gitte ryngꝭes
This Carpenter woke and herde him singꝭes
And spak vn to his wife and saide anone
What Alisou heres þu not Absolou
Þat chaunted thus vnder oure boures walle
And she answerid here husbond ther with alle
Yis god wote Iohn I here it eủer/rey dele
Þis passith forthe what will ye than but wele
Fro day to day this Ioly Absolou
So woweth hire þat him was wo be gone
He wakith alle the nyght and alle the day
He kemeth his lockes brode and made him gay
He woweth here be menes and brocage
And swore he wolde ben hir oune page
He syngeth brokyngꝭes as a nyghtyngale
He sente hir pyment meth and spiced ale
And wafres pypingꝭes hote oute the glede
And for she was of the toun he profrid her mede
For sum folke will be wonīmen for riches
And sum for strokes and sum for gentilnes
Some time to shewe his highnes ⁊and maistre
He plaieth the herawde vpon a scaffold hey
But what availith hy in this caas
So loueth she this hende Nicholas
Þat Absolou may blawe þe bukhorn
He ne had for his labour but a scorne
And þus she maketh Absolou here ape
All his ernest is turned to a Iape
Forsothe this prouerbe is nolie
Men sey thus alwey the nyght slie
Mail þe ferre loıı̄une to be lothe
For though that absolou be woode or wrothe
Be cause that he ferre was from here sight
Þis nyghe Nicholas stode in his light
Nowe bere þe well hende Nicholas
For absolou may waille and sing allas
And so bifell it on a satirday ¶
This Carpent̉er/re was gone to Oseney
And hende Nicholas and Alisou
Accordid were to this conclusiou
Þat Nicholas shall shapen him a wyle
Þis sely Ielus husbonde to begile
And yif so be þe game wente aright
She shulde slepe in his arme alnight
For this was his desire and hirs also
And right anone with oute wordis mo
Þis Nicholas no lenger wolde tarie
But doth full softe vn to his Chaumbre cary
Bothe mete and drinke for a day or tueyn
And to hire husbonde badde hire for to seien
Yif that he askid aft̉er/re Nicholas
She shuld sey she nyste wher he was
Of alle that day she sawe him not with eye
She trowid that he was yn sum maladie
For no crie the maide dede calle
He nolde answer for not that might be falle
This passith forthe alle the satirday
Þat Nicholas stille in his bedde lay
And ete and slepte and did what him leste
Tille sunday þat þe sonne gothe to reste
This sely Carpenter had grete mervaill
Of Nicholas or what thingꝭes might him ayle
And saide I am a dred be seinte Thomas
It stondith not aright with Nicholas
God shelde þat he deide sodenly
This worlde is nowe full sikerly
I saugh this day a cors born to chirche
Þat on monday laste was I sawe werche
Go vp qd he to his knaue anone
Clepe atte his dore and knok with a stone
Loke howe it is and telle me boldely
This knaue went vp full sturdely
And atte Chambre dore while he stode
He cried and knockid as he were wode
What howe what do ye maister Nicholay
Howe may ye slepe as this longe day
But all for not he herde neủer/re aworde
An hole he founde lowe vnder a borde
Þer as the Catte was wouned for to crepe
And atte a hole he lokid yn full depe
And atte laste he had of him a sight
This Nicholas sate euer gapingꝭes vp right ¶
As he had kekid on the newe Mone
And doun he gothe and tolde his Maist̉er/re sone
In what aray he sawe this ilke a man
This Carpent̉er/re to blisse him be gan
And seide helpe vs seinte Frysebid
Aman wote litill what shall him be tide
This man is falle with his astronomye
In to some wodenes or in to some Agonye
I thought well howe it shuld be
Men shulde not knowe of goddis priuete
Ȝe blesse be he alwey the lewde man

AT Sarray in the land of Tartarye
Ther dwelte a kyng that werreyed Russye

Which in his tyme was of so greet renoun

So excellent a lord in alle thyng
Hym lakked noght that longed to a kyng

Of his corage as any Centre stable
Yong fressh and strong in armes desirous
As any Bachiler of al his hous
A fair persone he was and fortunat
And kepte alwey so wel Roial estat
That ther nas no wher swich another man
This noble kyng this Tartre Cambyuskan
Hadde two sones on Elfeta his wyf

That oother sone was clepid Cambalo
A doghter hadde this worthy kyng also
That yongest was and highte Canacee
But for to telle yow al hir beautee
It lyth nat in my tonge nyn my konnyng
I dar nat vndertake so heigh a thyng
Myn englyssh eek is insufficient
It moste been a Rethor excellent

I am noon swich I moot speke as I kan
And so bifel that whan this Kambyuskan

And by hir beddes heed she made a Muwe
And couered it with veluettes blue
In signe of trouthe that is in wommen sene
And al withoute the Muwe is peynted grene
In which were peynted alle thise false fowles
As been thise tydyues terceletz and Owles
Right for despit were peynted hem bisyde
And Pyes on hem for to crye and chyde
Thus lete I Canacee hir hauk kepyng
I wol namoore as now speke of hir ryng
Til it come eft to purpos for to seyn
How that this Faukon gat hir loue ageyn
Repentant as the storie telleth vs
By mediacion of Cambalus
The kynges sone of which I to yow tolde
But hennes fort I wol my proces holde
To speke of auentures and of batailles
That neuere yet was herd so greet meruailles
First wol I telle yow of Cambyuskan
That in his tyme many a Citee wan
And after wol I speke of Algarsyf
How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
For whom ful ofte in gret peril he was
Ne hadde he been holpen by the Steede of bras
And after wol I speke of Cambalo
That faught in lystes with the bretheren two
For Canacee er that he myghte hir wynne
And ther I lefte I wol ayein bigynne
Explicit secunda pars
Incipit tercia pars
Explicit secunda pars Et in- cipit tercia pars
Appollo whirleth vp his Char so hye
Til that the god Mercuries hous the slye
Here endith the Squyeres tale as meche as Chaucer made
Sic desinit Fabula Armigeri
Ther can be found no more of this for- sayd tale whyche I haue ryght dilygently ser- chyd in many dyuers scoppyes
Ther is nomore of the squyers tale

body.fw: ¶ Here beginnyth the ꝓprolog of the marchaunte

div.l: IN faith squier thou haste the right wele quitt
And gentili I pise right wele thi witt
LQuod the marchᵃunt considering the youthe
So felingli thou spekist I allouthe
As to my dome ther is non that is her
Of elloquens that shal be thi per
If that thou leve god ȝif the goode chᵃunce
And in vertu send the contenuaunce
For of the I haue grete deinte
I haue a son and be the trenite
I had leủer/re than . xx li worth londe
Thouth it right now wer fal into my honde
He wer a man of soche discrecion
As ye bene fre in possession
But if aman be vertuouse withall
I haue my son snibbid and yit I shal
For he til vertue listith not entende
But forto play atte deese and to dispende
And to lose al that he hathe is his vsage
And had leủer/re talken with a page
Than to comen with a gentil wight
Wher he might lerne gentilnesse of right
Strawe for your gentilnes quod our hooste
What marchᵃunt ꝑper/parde wel thou wooste
That iche of you mote tellen atte leste
A tale or twoo or breken his beheste
That knowe I wele qˢ the marchᵃunt c̉er/retaine
I pi you hauith not me in disdeine
Though to this man I speke a worde or ij
Tel on thi tale withoute wordes moo
Gladli ʆser/sir hoste qd he I wil obey
Vnto your wil now herkith what I say
I wil you not contrari in no wise
As ferr as my wittes may suffice
I pi to god that it may please you
Than woot I wele that it is good ynow

TThe tale of the marchᵃunt
Of Ianuary and May ¶
Whilom ther was dwellyng in lumbardie
A worthi knight that was borne in pauy
In which he leuid in grete ꝓprosꝑper/parite
And sexti yere a wifeles man was he
And folued ay his bodili delite
On women ther as was his apitite
As doon the foles that been secler
And when he was passid xl yer
Wer it for holinesse or for dotage
I kan not sei but seche a grete corage
Had this knight to be a wedded man
That day and night he dothe al that he can
To espie wher he might wedded be
P̉er/reyng our lorde to graunte him that he
Mitht ones knowe of that blisful life
That is betwyxt an husbond and his wife
And forto love vnder the holi bonde
With which god man and woman bonde
Non other life qd he is worth a bene
For wedloc is so esi and so clene
That in this worlde it is a ꝑper/paradise
Thus saide this olde knight that was so wise
And certainli as sothe as god is kyng
To take a wife it is a gloriouse thing
And nameli when aman is olde and hoore
Than is a wife the frite of his tresore
Than sholde he take ayonge wife and afaire
On which he might engendre his heire
And lede his life in ioye and solace
Wher as thise bachelers sing allas
Whan that thei finde eny adủer/resite
In love which is but childish vanite
And truli it sittith wele to be soo
That bachelers haue oft peyne and woo
On britil grounde thei bilde and britilnesse
Thei fude when thei wene sekernesse
Thei leue but as a brid or a beeste
In liberte and vnder none areste
Ther as a wedded man in his estate
Lyvith a life blisful and ordinate
Vnder this yooke of mariage y bounde
Wele may his herte in ioy and blis habounde
For who kan be so buxom as a wife
Who is so trewe and so entendife
To kepe him sike and hole as his make
For welle or woo she will him not forsake
She is not weri him to love and serue
Though he lie bedrede til he sterve ¶
And yit som clerks sei it is not soo
Of which Theo is on of thoo
What force though theo ferst list to lye
Ne take no wife quod he for husbondrie
As forto spare in householde thi dispence
A triew ʆser/siruant dothe more diligence
Thi goode to kepe than thin oune wife
For she wil claime halfe parte al hir life
And if thou be sike so god me saue
Thi veri frendes or a triewe knave
Wil kepe the better than she that waitithay
After thi goode and hathe done many a day
And if thou take awife
And leve in langore and disease al thi life
This sentence and an hundred tymes worse
Writith this man ther god his bones curse

l.seg: But take no kepe of soche vanite

div.l: Defie Theos craft and herke me
A wife is godes yift verile
Al other man yiftes hardili right
As londes rentes pasture or comune
Or moebles al bene yiftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on the walle
But drede not if pleinli speke I shal
A wife wil laste and in thine house endure
Wel leng the list ꝑper/paraventur
Mariage is a ful grete sacrament
He which hathe no wife I holde him shente
He levith al helpeles and dissolate
I speke of folke of seculer estate
And herke whi I sei not this for noght
That womman is for mannes helpe wrought
The high god when he had Adam maked
He sigh him alone bely naked
God of his goodenes seide than
Lete vs make an helpe vnto this man
Like to him self and than he made him Eve
Her may ye her and her may ye see
That wife is mannes helpe and his comforte
His ꝑper/paradise t̉er/rerestr and his disporte
So buxom and so vertuose is she
Thei moste nedes leve in vnite
On flesh thei bene and on flesh as I gesse
Hathe but on herte in wele and in distresse
A wife a seint marie benedicite
How might aman haue eny adủer/resite
That hathe a wife certes I can not sey
The blisse that is be twixt hem twey
Ther may no tunge telle ne herte thynke ¶left
If he be pore she helpith him to swynke
She kepith his goode and wastith neủer/re adele
Al that hir husbond luste she likes wele
She saies not ones nay when he saithe yee
Dothis saithe he al redi sir saithe she
O blisful ordere O wedloc preciouse
Thou arte so meri and eke so vertuose
And so comended and so approved eke
That eny man that holdith him worthe a leke
Vpon his bare barekeknees aught al his live
Thou kyng his god that him hathe sent a wife
Or elles prei to god him forto sende
A wife to laste vnto his lives ende
For then his life is sett in sikernesse
He maynot be disceived as I gesse
So that he werke after his wifes rede
Than may he boldeli kepe vp his hede
Thei bene so trewe and ther withal so wise
For which if thou wilt wirken as the wise
Do alway so as wōmmen wil the rede
Loo how that Iacob as thise clerkes rede
Bi goode counsaile of his moder Rebeke
Bonde the kides skyn a boute his necke
For which his faders blissyng he wan
Loo Iudif eke as stories tell kan
Be goode counsaile she godes peple kepte
And slowe oliphernus while he slepte
Lo Abigaile bi goode counsaile how she
Saued hir husbonde sabal when that he
Sholde haue bene slayne and loke aster also
Be goode counsaile deliủer/reed oute of woo
The poeple of god and made him Mardoche
Of Assuere enhaunced forto be
Ther is no thing in gre suꝑper/parlatife
As saithe seneck a boue an humble wife
Suffre thi wifes tvnge as Caton bidde
She shal comaunde and thou shalte soffr it
And yit she shal wel obey of courtesey
A wife is keper of thin husbondrie
Welle may the sike man be waile and wepe
Ther as ther is no wife the house forto kepe
I warne the if wiseli that thou wilt wirche
Loue well thi wife as Crist louith his chirche
If thou louist thi self thou louest thiwife
No man hatith his flesh but in his life
He fostreth it and therfore bid I the
Cherise thi wife or thou shalte neủer/re thee
Husbond and wife what so men Iape or play right
Of worldele folke holden the siker way
Thei bene so knit ther may no harme be tide
And nameli on the wifes side
For which this Ianuary of whom I tolde
Considered hathe within his daies olde
The lusti life the vertuouse quiete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes on aday he sente
To tellen hem theffecte of his entente
With face sad this tale he hathe hem tolde
He saithe frendes I am hore and olde
And almoost god woot on my pittes brinke
Vpon my soule somwhat moste I thinke
I haue my bodi folili despendid
Blessid be god that it shal be amendid
For I wil be certayne a weddid man
And that anone in al the haste that I can
Vnto som maide faire and tendre of age
I prey you shapith for my mariage
Al sodeinli for I wil not abide
And I wil fonde on me side
To aspie to whom I may be wedded hastili
But for as moche as ye bene moo than I
Ye shal seche athing rather aspien
Than I and where my liste were to allien
But on thing warne I you my frendes dere
I wil non olde wife haue in no maner
Ye shal not passe xx yere certayne
Olde fissh and yonge flessh wolde I haue faine
Bett is quod he a pike than a pikerel
And bet than befe olde the tender vele
I wil no woman xxx wynter of age
It is but bene stree and grete forage
And eke thise olde widowes god it woot
Thai can so moche crafte on wades boot
Somoche broken harme when hem leste
That with thaime sholde I neủer/re leue in reste
For sondri scoles makith subtile clerkes
Woman of many scoles halfe a clerke is
But certainli ayonge thing may men gie
Right as men may warme wax with hondes plie
Wherfore I say you pleinli yn a clause
I wil non olde wife haue right for this cause
For if so were I had soche mischaunce
That I in hir ne cowde haue no plesaunce
Then sholde I lede my life in avoutrie
And streight to the devil when I deye
Ne childre sholde I non vpon hir geten
Yit had me leuir houndes had me eten
Then myne heritage sholde falle ¶
Into strange honde and thus I telle you alle
I dote nought I woot the cause whi
Men sholde wed and ferthermore woot I
Ther speket many aman of mariage
That woot no more of it than woot my page
For which causes men sholde take a wife
If he may not leve chaste in his life
Take him a wif with grete deuocion
Bi cause of lefful ꝓprocreacion
Of children to the honour of god aboue
And not oneli for ꝑper/paramour or love
And for thei sholde lecheri eschewe
And yelde here dett when it is due
Or for iche of hem sholde helpe other
In myschief as suster shal the brother
And live in chastite ful holili
But sires bi leve that am not I
For god bethenked I dar make auᵘnt
I fele my lemys starke and suffisaunt
To do al that aman longith too
I woot my self best what I can doo
Though I be hore I fare as dothe atre
That blossemeth er the frute woxen be
And blosmy tree is nethir drie ne dede
I fele me nowher hore save on myne hede
Myne herte and al my lymes bene as grene
As laurer thourgh the yer is forto sene
And sethen ye haue herde al myne entente
I pᵃy you to my counsaile ye wollen assente
Diuerse men diủer/resli him tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Some blamed it some pised it certayne
But atte laste shortli forto seyne
As alday fallith altercacion
Betwixt frendes indisputacion
Ther fel a strife betwixt his brethren two
Of which that on was called placebo
Iustinis shortli called was that other
Placebo saide O Ianuare brother
Ful litel nede had ye my lorde so dere
Counseile to aske of eny that is here
But that ye be so ful of sapience
That you ne liketh for your high pʳdence
To weyve fro the worde of Salamon
This worde saide he til vs euerichoon
Werke al thing bi counsaile thus saide he
And then shalte thou not repent the
But though that Salamon spake seche a worde
Myne oune der brother and my lorde ¶
So wissli god my soule bring at Reste
I holde your oune counsaile is the beste
For brother myne of me take this motife
I have now bene a Court man al my life
As god woot though I vnworthi be
I have stonden in ful grete degree
A bowte lordes in ful grete estate
Yit had I neủer/re with noon of hem debate
I neủer/re hem contraried trevly
I wote wele my lorde kan more than I
What that he saithe I holde it ferme ⁊and stable
I say the same or elles thing semblable
A ful grete foole is eny counsailoure
That serveth eny lorde of grete honoure
That dare presume or ellis thenken it
That his counsaile sholde passe his lordes witt
Nay lordes be no fooles be my fay
Ye have your selven shewed here to day
So high sentence so holili and wele
That I consente and conferme everi dele
Your wordes al and your opinioun
Be god ther is no man in al this toun
Ne in Itale covde bet haue saide
Crist halt him of this counsaile wele paide
And truli it is an high corage
Of eny man that stepen is in age
Take a yonge wife bi my fader kyn
Your herte hongith on a ioli pyn
Dothe now and in this mater right as ye liste
For finalli I holde it for the beste
Iustinus that ay stil sate and herde
Right in this wise he to placebo answerde
Now brother myne be pacient I you pᵃy
Sethen ye have saide and herkeneth what I say
Senek amonge other wordes wise
Seith that aman aught him wele avise
To whom he yevith his londe or his catel
And seithe I aught to avise me right wel
To whom I yeve my goode a way fro me
Wel moche more I aght to avise me
To whom I yeve my bodi for alway
I warne you wele it is no childes play
To taken a wife with outen avisement
Men moste enquere this is myne assent
Wher she be wise and sobre or drvnkelewe
Or prowde or ellis other wayes a shrewe
A chidester or elles a wast̉er/re of the goode
Or riche or pore or elles mannish wood
Al be it so that no man finde shal
Noon in the worlde that trottith hoole in al
Ne man ne beest soche as men cowde devise
But natheles it aght ynough suffise
With eny wife if it so wer she had ¶
Moo goode theves than hir vices bad
And al this askith leiser forto enquere
For god it woot I have wepte many a tere
Ful priveli sithen that I had a wife
Praise whoso wil a weddid mannes life
Certain I fynde in it but coste and care
Of obseruᵃnces of al blisses bare
And yit god wote my neighbourghe a bowte
And nameli of women many a rowte
Seyen that I have the mooste stedfaste wife
And eke the mekest that berith life
But I woot beste wher wryngith me my shoo
Ye may for me right as you liketh doo
Avisith you ye bene a man of age
How that ye entren in mariage
And nameli with a yonge wife and afaire
Bi him that made water erthe and ayre
Ye yongest man that is in al this rowte
Is besi ynough to bryngyn it abowte
To have his wife allone tristith me
Ye shul not plesen hir fulli yeres thre
This is to sayne to doo hir ful plesaunce
A wife asketh many an obseruᵃnce
I pi you that ye be not yvel paide
Wel qd Ianuari and haste thou saide
Strawe for thi Senek and for thi ꝓproverbes
I counte not apanyere ful of herbes
Of scole termes wisere man than thou
As thou haste herde assentid right now
To my pʳpose placebo what say ye
I say it is a coursed man qd he
That letteth matrimony sekerly
And with that worde thay resen sodeinli
And bene assentid fulli that he sholde
Be weddid when him liste and wher he wolde
High fantasie and coriouse besinesse
Fro day to day gan in the sovle impresse
Of Ianuari abowte his mariage
Many faire shap and many faire visage
Ther passith thorugh his herte night be night
And whoso toke a myrrour polished bright
And set it in a comune market place
Than sholde he see many a figure face
Bi his mirrour in the same wise
Gan Ianuare in his thought devise
Of maydenes that dwellid him beside
He wist not where he might abide
For ith that on have beawte in hir face
An other stonte so in the peples grace
For hir sadnesse and hir benignite ¶
That of the poeple grettest voice hath she
And some were riche and had bad name
But natheles betwixt ernest and game
He atte laste appointid him on oon
And lete al other fro his herte goon
And ches hir of his auctorite
For love is blinde alday and may not see
And when that he to his bed is brought
He purtraied in his herte and in his thought
Hir fresh beawte and hir age tendre
Hir myddil smalle hir armes longe and sklender
Hir wise goủer/renaunce hir gentilnesse
Hir womanli beryng and hir sadnesse
And when that he on hir was condesended
Him thouwht his choise might not be amended
For when that he himself concludid had
Him thought iche other mannes witt was bad
That Impossible it were to replie
Agayne his choise this was his fantasie
His frendes sent he to at his instaunce
And pied hem to do him that plesaunce
That hastili thai wolde to him come
He wolde abrigge hir labour al and some
Nedith no more for him goo ne ride
He was appoyntid where he wolde abide
Placebo came and his frendes sone
And altherferst he bad hem al abone
That non of hem non argumentz make
Agayne the pʳpos which he hathe take
Which pʳpose was plesyng to god saide he
And verri grounde of ꝓprosꝑper/parite
He saide ther was amaiden in the toune
Which that of beaute had grete renoune
Al were it soo she wer of smal degree
Suffisith him youthe and hir beavte
Which maide he saide he wolde have he saide to his wife
To lede in ease and holinesse his life
And thankid god that he might han hir al
That no wight his blisse ꝑper/parceyve shal
And peied to hem to laboren in this nede
And shapen that he faile nat to spede
For then he saide that his spirite was atese
Then is quod he nothing that may displese
Save on thing pⁱriketh in my conscience
The which I wil reherse in your psence
I have quod he herde saye ful yore a goo
Ther may no man have ꝑper/parfite blisses twoo
This is to say in Erthe and eke in heven
For though he kepe him fro the sinnes vij
And eke fro eủer/rei branche of that tree
Yit is ther so ꝑper/parfite felicite ¶
And so grete ease and luste in mariage
That eủer/re I am agaste now in myne age
That I shal lede soche a mery life
Now so delicat withouten woo and strife
That I shal have myne heven in erthe here
For sith that verray heven is bought so dere
With tribulacion and grete penaunce
How sholde I than that leve in soche plesaunce
As alle weddid men dothe with here wifes
Come to the blisse that Crist eterne on life is
This is my drede and ek my brether twey
Assaileth me this question I pray
Iustinus which that hatith his foly
Answerde anon right in Iapery
For he wolde his longe tale abregge
He wolde non auctorite allegge
But saide sir so ther be non obstacle
Other than this god of his high miracle
And of his mercy may so for you wirche
That er ye have your right of holi chirche
Ye may repente of wedded mennes life
In which ye sayne ther is no woo ne strife
And elles god forbede but he sent
A wedded man him grace to repent
Wel oft rather than a sengle man
And therfore sir the beste rede that I can
Dispeire you nought but haue in your memory
Paraunter she may be your purgatory
She may be goddis mene and goddes wipp
Than shal your soule vpto heven skypp
Swither than dothe an arwe oute of abowe
I hope to god here after ye shal knowe
That ther is non so grete felicite
In mariage ne neủer/re mote shal be
That you shal lette of your saluacion
Soo as ye vse as skil is and reson
The lustes of your wife attempalli
And that ye plese hir not amorousli
And that ye kepe you eke fro othir sinne
Mi tale is done my witt is thynne
Benot agaste my brother der
But late vs waden oute of this mater
The wife of bathe if ye have vnderstonde
Of mariage which we have on honde
Declared hathe ful well in litle space
Fareth now wele god have you now in his grace
And with that this Iustyn and his brother
Have take hir leve and iche of hem of other
For when thai sawe it moste nedes be
Thay wroughten so be sly and wise trete
That she this maiden that Mayus hight
As hasteli as eủer/re that she myght
Shal wedded be vnto this Ianuare ¶
I trow it were ful longe for you to tary
If I you tolde of eủer/rey scrift and bonde
Be which she was feffed in his londe
Or forto herken of hir riche aray
But finalli y comen is that day
That to the chirche bothe bene thay wente
Forto receyve the holi sacrament
Forth comyth the preest with stole abowte his neck
And bad hir be like Sarra and Rebeck
In wisdome and in trouthe of mariage
And saide his orison as his vsage
And crovcheth hem and bad god sholde hem blisse
And made al siker ynough with holynesse
Thus bene thei weddid with solempnite
And atte laste sittith he and she
With other worthi folke vpon the deise
Al ful of ioy is the palleis
And ful of instrumentz and of vitaile
The mooste deintees of al ytaile
Beforne hem stode instrumentz of soche soune
That Orpheus ne of thebes Amphion
Ne maden not soche a melodie
At eủer/rey course than came lowde mynstralcy
That neủer/re tromped Ioab forto here
Ne he Theodomas half so clere
At Thebes when the Cite was in dovte
Bacus the wyn hem shenketh al abowte
And venus laugheth on eủer/rey wight
For Ianuare was be come her knight
And wolde bothe assaye his corage
In liberte and eke in mariage
And with hir fire bronde in hir honde abowte
Daunceth before the bride and al the rowte
And certaynli I dare right wele say thus
Ineneus that god of oflove is weddyng is
Sawe neủer/re his life so mery a wedded man
Holde thi pese thou poet Marcian
That writist thilke weddyng mery
Of her philogre and he Mercurie
And of the songe that the muses songe
To smal is bothe thi penne and eke thi tvnge
Forto discriven of this mariage
When tendre youthe hathe weddid stowpyng age
Ther is soche mirthe that may not be wreten
Assaieth it your self and than may ye witen
If that I lie or noo in this mater
Maius that sit with so benigne chere
Hir tobeholde it semed fairy
Quene Ester loked neủer/re with soche an yhe
On Assuer so meke a loke hathe shee
I may you not devise al hir beavte ¶
But thus moche of hir beaute tel I may
That she was like the bright morne of May
Fulfilled of al beaute and plesaunce
This Ianuare is ravished in a traunce
And eủer/rey tyme he loke in hir face
But in his herte he gan hir to manace
That he that night in armes wolde hir streyne
Harder than eủer/re paris did Eleyne
But natheles yit had he grete pite
That thilke night offenden hir moste he
And thought allas o tender creature
Now wolde god ye might endure
Al my corage it is so sharpe and kene
I am a gaste ye shal it not welle sustene
But god forbede that I did al my myght
Now wolde god it were woxen night
And that the night wolde laste eủer/re moo
I wolde that al this peple were agoo
And finalli he dothe al his laboure
As he beste might saving his honour
To haste fro the mete in subtile wise
The tyme came that reson was to rise
And after that thei daunce and drynke faste
And spices al abowte the howse thei kaste
And ful of ioy and blisse is eủer/rey man
Al but a squier hight damyan
Which karve before the knight many aday
He was so ravished of his lady May
That for peyne he was nigh wood
Almoost he swelte and swouned as he stood
So sore hathe venus smeten him with his honde
As she bare it daunsyng in hir honde
And to his bed he wente hastili
Nomore of him attistyme speke I
But ther I lete him wepe ynough and pleyne
Til fresh May wil rue on his peyne left
O ꝑper/parilouse fire that in the bedstre bredith
O familier foo that his service bedith
O seruᵃnt traitour fals homeli hewe
Like to the Eddre in bosom slie fals vntrieve
God shelde vs al fro your acqueyntaunce
O Ianuare drvnken in plesaunce
In mariage se how thi damyan
Thine oune squiere and thi borne man
Entendith to doo the villeny
God graunte the thine homeli foo to espie
For in this worlde nis werse pestilence
Than homeli foo alday in thi psence
Parfourmed hathe the sonne his arke divrne ¶
No lenger may the bodi of him soiourne
O thorisonte as in that latitude
Night with his mantel that is derke and rude
Gan oủer/re sprede the Emysperes abowte
For which departid is the lusti rowte
Fro Ianuarie with thanke on eủer/rei side
Home to their houses lustili thei ride
Where thai done her thingꝭes as them list
And when thei sawe her tyme go to reste
Sone after that this hasti Ianuarie
Wil goo to bed he wil no lenger tari
He drynkith ypocrase Clarre and vernage
Of spices hoot to encresen his corage
And many a letuari had ful fine
Soche as the coursid monke dan Constantine
Hathe writen in his booke de Coitu
To eten hem al he wolde nothing eschewe
And to his prive frendes thus saide he
For goddes love as sone as it may be
Let voiden al this house in courteise wise
And thei haue done right as he can devise
Men drunken and the travers drawe anone
And the bride was brought a bed as stil as stone
And when the bed was with the preest blessid
Oute of the Chambre hathe euery wight him dressid
And Ianuarie hathe faste in armes take
His fresh may his paradise his make
He lullith hir he kissith hir ful ofte
With thicke bristells on his berde vnsofte
Like the skyn of an hounde fish sharpe as brere
For he was shave al niewe in his manere
He rubbith hir a bowte hir tendre face
And saide thus allas I mote trespase
To you my spowse and you greteli offende
Or tyme come that I wil doune discende
But natheles consides this quod he
Ther is no werke mon what so eủer/re he be
That may welle and hastili
This wil be done at leiser ꝑper/parfitli
It is no force how longe that we play
In trewe wedloc coupled be we twey
And blissid be the yocke that we be yn
For in actes we may doo syn
Aman may do no synne with his wife
Ne hurten himself with his oune knife
For we have leve to play vs bi the lawe
Thus laboreth he til the day gan dawe
And than he takith a soppe in fine clarre
And vpright in his bed sittith he
After that he songe ful lowde and clere ¶
And kist his wif and made wantoune chere
He was al coltish ful of ragerie
And ful of Iargon as a fleckid pie
The slack skyn abowte his necke shakith
While that he songe so chᵃuntith he and crakith
But god woot what that may thought in hir herte
When she him sawe vpsittyng in his sherte
In his nigh cappe with his necke lene
She pisith not his playyng worthe a bene
Than saide he thus my reste wil I take
Now day is comen I may no lenger wake
And doune he leide his hede and slept til pⁱrime
And afterwarde when he sawe his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie but fresh May
Helde hir chambr vnto the fourth day
As vsage is of wifes for the beste
For eủer/rey labour somtyme moste haue reste
Or elles longe may he not endure
This is to sayne no lives creature
Be it fish brid beest or man
Now wil I speke of woful Damyan
That languishith for love as ye shal her
Therfore I speke to him in this maner
I say o seli Damyan allas left
Answer to my demaunde in this caas
How shalte thou to thi ladi fresh may
Tel thi woo she wil alway say nay
Eke if thou speke she wil thi woo bewrey
God be thine helpe I can no better say
This sike Damyan in Venus fire
So brenneth that he dieth for desire
For which he put his life in aventure
No lenger myght he in this life endure
But priveli a penner gan he borewe
And in a lettre wroot he al his sorewe
In aman of a compleint or alay
Vnto his fair fresh lady May
And a purse of selke henge on his serke
He hathe it put and leide at his herte
The moone that at none was thilke day
That Ianuarie hathe weddid fresh May
Iuno and Taure was into Cancre gleden
Solonge hathe Mayus in hir chambr abiden
As custume is to thise noblis al
A bride shal not eten in the hal
Til daies iiij or iij daies atte leeste
I passid bene than lete hir goo to feeste
The fourth day complete fro none to none
When that high masse was I done
In hall sitt this Ianuarie and May
As fresh as is the somers day
And so befel how that this goode man ¶
Remembred him vpon this Damyan
And saide seint Mari how may it be
That Damyan entendith not to me
Is he ay sike or how may this betide
His squiers which that stoden ther beside
Excused him be cause of his sikenesse
Which lettid him to doo his besinesse
Non other cause might make him tarie
That me forthinkith quod Ianuarie
He is a Ientil squier be my trouthe
If that he deide it wer grete pite and rowthe
He is wise discrete and eke secre
As eny man I woot of his degre
And therto manli and eke ʆser/siruisable
And forto be athrifti man right able
But efter mete as sone as eủer/re I may
I wil my self visite him and eke may
And do him al the comforte that I can
And for that woorde him blessed many aman
That of his bounte and of his gentilnesse
He wolde so comforten in sikenesse
His squier for it was a gentil dede
Dame quod this Ianuarie take goode hede
At aftir mete ye with your women al
When ye haue bene in chambre oute of this hal
That ye al goo to this Damyan
Dothe him disporte he is a Ientil man
And tellith him that I wil him visite
Have I nothing but restid me a lite
And spede you faste for I wil abide
Til that ye slepe faste bi my side
And with that worde he gan to him calle
A squier that was Marchal of his hal
And tolde him certayne thinges that he wolde
This fresh May hathe hir streight waye y holde
With al hir wemen vnto Damyan
Doune bi his beddis side sit she than
Comfortyng him as goodeli as she may
This Damyan when that his tyme he say
In secrete wise his purpos and eke his bil
In which that he wreten had his wille
Hathe put into hir honde withouten more
Save that he siketh wonder depe and sore
And softh to hir right thus saide he
Mercy and that þe not discouer me
For I am but dede if this thinge be kid
This purse hathe she in hir bosom hid
And wente hir way ye gett no more of me
But vnto Ianuarie comen is she
That on his beddes side sitt fulsofte
And takith hir and kissith hir ful ofte
And leide him to slepe right anon
She feyned hir as that she moste goon
Ther as eủer/rey wight hathe nede
And when she of this bil hathe take hede ¶
She rent it al to cloutes atte laste
And in the prive softli it caste
Who studieth nowe but faire fresh May
Adoune be olde Ianuarie she lay
That slepte til the cough hathe him awaked
Anon he preide strepen hir al naked
He wolde he saide haue of hir som plesaunce
He saide hir clothis did him encombraunce
And she obeieth be hir leif or lothe
But leste preciouse folke be with me wrothe
How that he wrought I dar not to you tell
Or whethir it thought paradise orhell
But here I lete hem werken in hir wise
Til even songe ryng and that thei moste arise
Were it be desteny or be aventur
Wer it bi influence or be nature
Or constillacion that in soche estate
The heven stood that tyme fortunate
As forto put a bil of venus werkes
For al thing hathe tyme as seyen thise clerkes
To eny woman forto gete hir love
I can not sey but grete god above
That knoweth that non acte is causeles
He deme al for I wil holde my pese
¶ But sothe is this how that this fresh may
Hathe taken soche inpression that day
Of pite on this sike damyan
That fro hir herte she ne drive can
The remembraunce forto done him ease
Certayne though she whom this thing displease
I reche not for her I him assure
To love him beste of eny creature
Though he no more had but his sherte
Lo pite renneth sone in Ientil herte
Here may ye see how excellent fraunchise
In women is when thei narowh avise
Som Tiraunte ther is as ther bene many one
That hathe an herte as harde as eny stone
Which wolde haue leten him sterven in the place
Wel rathir than grauntid him hir grace
And hem reioisen in hir cruel pride
And recke not to bene an homicide
This Ientil May fullfilled of pite
Right of hir honde a letter maked she
In which she grauntid him hir veri grace
Ther lacketh not oneli but day and place
Wher she might to his luste suffice
For it shal be right as he wil devise
And when she saughe hir tyme on aday
To visite Damyan gothe May
And softli doune this lettr she thriste

div.l: (base) Pouerte is thyng althogh it seme elenge

div.l: (base) Here endeth the Wyues tale of Bathe
(base) Explicᵗ
(base) ¶ The prologe of the Freres tale

(base) ¶ Peter / so been wommen of the Styves

(base) ¶ Pees with myschaunce / and with mysauenture

(base) ¶ And so bifel / that ones on a day

(base) ¶ Sire quod this Somnour / hayl / and wel atake
(base) ¶ Wel come quod he / and euery good felawe

(base) ¶ This Somnour hym answerde / and seyde nay

div.l: (base) He dorste nat for verray filthe and shame

(base) I am vnknowen / as in this contree
(base) Of thyn aqueyntance / I wolde praye thee

(base) I haue gold / and siluer in my cheste

(base) ¶ This Somnour / which that was / as ful of Iangles

(base) ¶ Now by my trouthe / brother deere / seyde he

(base) Algate / by sleighte / or by violence

(base) ¶ Now certes quod this Somnour / so fare I

(base) Quod this Somnour / in this mene whyle

(base) Make ye yow newe bodyes / thus alway

(base) ¶ Nay quod this Somnour / that shal nat bityde

div.l: (base) Com of / and lat me ryden hastily

(base) No children hadde he mo in al his lif
(base) Fair was this mayde in excellent beautee
(base) Abouen euery wight that man may see
(base) For Nature hath with souereyn diligence
(base) Yformed hire in so greet excellence
(base) As thogh she wolde seyn lo I nature
(base) Thus kan I forme and peynte a creature
(base) Whan that me list who kan me countrefete
(base) Pigmalion noght thogh he ay forge and bete
(base) Or graue or peynte for I dar wel seyn
(base) Apelles zanzis sholde werche in veyn
(base) Outher to graue or peynte or forge or bete
(base) If they presumeden me to countrefete
(base) For he that is the formere principal
(base) Hath maked me his vicaire general
(base) To forme and peynten erthely creaturis
(base) Right as me list and ech thyng in my cure is

div.l: (base) Vnder the Moone that may wane and waxe
(base) And for my werk right no thyng wol I axe
(base) My lord and I been ful of oon acord
(base) I made hire to the worship of my lord
(base) So do I alle myne othere creatures
(base) What colour that they han or what figures
(base) Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye
(base) This mayde of age twelue yeer was and tweye
(base) In which that nature hadde swich delit
(base) For right as she kan peynte a lilye whit
(base) And reed a Rose right with swich peynture
(base) She peynted hath this noble creature
(base) Er she were born vpon hir lymes free
(base) Wher as by right swiche colours sholden be
(base) And Phebus dyed hath hir tresses grete
(base) Lyk to the stremys of his burned hete
(base) And if that excellent was hir beautee
(base) A thousand fold moore vertuous was she
(base) In hire ne lakked no condicioun
(base) That is to preyse as by discrecioun
(base) As wel in goost as body chaast was she
(base) For which she floured in virginitee
(base) With all humilitee and abstinence
(base) With all atemperance and pacience
(base) With mesure eek of beryng and array
(base) Discreet she was in answeryng alway
(base) Thogh she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
(base) Hir facound eek ful wommanly and pleyn
(base) No countrefeted termes hadde she
(base) To seme wys but after hir degree
(base) She spak and alle hir wordes moore and lesse
(base) Sownynge in vertu and in gentilesse
(base) Shamefast she was in maydens shamefastnesse
(base) Constant in herte and euere in bisynesse
(base) To dryue hire out of ydel slogardye
(base) Bacus hadde of hir mouth right no maistrye
(base) For wyn and youthe dooth Venus encreesse
(base) As men in fyr wol casten oille or gresse
(base) And of hir owene vertu vnconstreyned
(base) She hath ful ofte tyme syk hir feyned
(base) For that she wolde fleen the compaignye
(base) Where likly was to treten of folye
(base) As is at festes reuels and at daunces
(base) That been occasions of daliaunces
(base) Swich thyng maken children for to be
(base) To soone rype and boold as men may se
(base) Which is ful perilous and hath be yoore
(base) For al to soone may they lerne loore
(base) Which afterward may greve þeim sore
(base) Of boldnesse whan she woxen is a wyf
(base) ¶ And ye Maistresses in youre olde lyf
(base) That lordes doghtres han in gouernance
(base) Ne taketh of my wordes no displesance
(base) Thenketh that ye been set in gouernynges
(base) Of lordes doghtres oonly for two thynges
(base) ¶ Owther for ye han kept youre honestee
(base) Or ellis ye han falle in freletee
(base) And knowen wel ynow the olde daunce
(base) And han forsaken fully swich meschaunce
(base) For euere mo therfore for Cristes sake
(base) To teche hem vertu looke that ye ne slake
(base) Kepeþ wel þo þat ȝe vndertake
(base) ¶ A theef of venyson that hath forlaft
(base) His likerousnesse and al his olde craft
(base) Kan kepe a Forest best of any man
(base) Now kepeth wel for if ye wole ye kan
(base) Looke wel that ye vnto no vice assente
(base) Lest ye be dampned for youre wikke entente
(base) For who so dooth a traytour is certeyn
(base) And taketh kepe of that that I shal seyn
(base) Of alle tresoun souerayn pestilence
(base) Is whan a wight bitrayseth Innocence
