div.l: (base) ¶ Ye fadres and ye modres eek also
(base) Thogh ye han children be it oon or mo
(base) Youre is the charge of al hir surueaunce
(base) Whil that they been vnder youre gouernaunce
(base) Beth war if by ensample of youre lyuynge
(base) Or by youre necligence in chastisynge
(base) That they perisse for I dar wel seye
(base) If that they doon ye shul it deere abeye
(base) Vnder a Shepherde softe and necligent
(base) The wolf hath many a sheep and lomb to rent
(base) Suffiseth oon ensample now as heere
(base) For I moot turne agayn to my matere
(base) ¶ This mayde of which I wol this tale expresse
(base) So kepte hir self hir neded no maistresse
(base) For in hir lyuyng maydens myghten rede
(base) As in a book euery good word or dede
(base) That longeth to a mayden vertuous
(base) She was so prudent and so bounteuous
(base) For which the fame out sproong on euery syde
(base) Bothe of hir beautee and hir bountee wyde
(base) That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
(base) That loued vertu saue enuye allone
(base) That sory is of oother mennes wele
(base) And glad is of his sorwe and his vnheele
(base) The doctor maketh this discripcioun
(base) This mayde vpon a day wente in the toun
(base) Toward a temple with hir moder deere
(base) As is of yonge maydens the manere
(base) ¶ Now was ther thanne a Iustice in that toun
(base) That gouernour was of that Regioun
(base) And so bifel this Iuge hise eyen caste
(base) Vpon this mayde auysynge hym ful faste
(base) As she cam forby ther as this Iuge stood
(base) Anoon his herte chaunged and his mood
(base) So was he caught with beautee of this mayde
(base) And to hymself ful pryuely he sayde
(base) This mayde shal by myn for any man
(base) Anon the feend in to his herte ran
(base) And taughte hym sodeynly that he by slyghte
(base) This mayden to his purpos wynne myghte
(base) For certes by no force ne by no meede
(base) Hym thoughte he was nat able for to speede
(base) For she was strong of freendes and eek she
(base) Confermed was in swich souerayn bountee
(base) That wel he wiste he myghte hir neuere wynne
(base) As for to make hire with hir body synne
(base) For which by greet deliberacioun
(base) He sente after a cherl was in the town
(base) Which that he knew for subtil and for bold
(base) This Iuge vnto this cherl his tale hath told
(base) In secree wise and made hym to ensure
(base) He sholde telle it to no creature
(base) And if he dide he sholde lese his heed
(base) Whan that assented was this cursed reed
(base) Glad was this Iuge and maked hym gret cheere
(base) And yaf hym yiftes preciouse and deere
(base) ¶ Whan shapen was al hir conspiracie
(base) Fro point to point how that his lecherie
(base) Parfourned sholde been ful subtilly
(base) As ye shul heere it after openly
(base) ¶ Hom goth the cherl that highte Claudius
(base) This false Iuge that highte Apius
(base) So was his name for this is no fable
(base) But knowen for historial thyng notable
(base) The sentence of it sooth is out of doute
(base) This false Iuge gooth now faste aboute
(base) To hasten his delit al that he may
(base) And so bifel soone after on a day
(base) This false Iuge as telleth vs the storie
(base) As we fine writen in olde storie
(base) As he was wont sat in his Consistorie
(base) And yaf his domes vpon sondry cas

div.l: (base) ¶ This false cherl cam forth a ful gret pas
(base) And seyde lord if that it be youre wille
(base) As dooth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In which I pleyne vpon Virginius
(base) And if that he wol seyn it is nat thus
(base) I wol it preue and fynde good witnesse
(base) That sooth is that my bille wol expresse
(base) ¶ This Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may nat yeue diffynytif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle and I wol gladly heere
(base) Thow shalt haue al right and no wrong heere
(base) ¶ Virginius cam to wite the Iuges wille
(base) And right anon was rad this cursed bille
(base) The sentence of it was as ye shul heere
(base) ¶ To yow my lord sire Apius so deere
(base) Sheweth youre poure seruant Claudius
(base) How that a knyght called Virginius
(base) Agayns the lawe agayn al equitee
(base) Holdeth expres agayn the wyl of me
(base) My seruant which that is my thral by right
(base) Which fro myn hous was stole vpon a nyght
(base) Whil that she was ful yong this wol I preue
(base) By witnesse lord so that it nat yow greue
(base) She nys his doghter nat what so he seye
(base) Wher to yow my lord the Iuge I preye
(base) Yeld me my thral if that it be youre wille
(base) Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
(base) ¶ Virginius gan vpon the cherl biholde
(base) But hastily er he his tale tolde
(base) And wolde haue proued it as sholde a knyght
(base) And eek by witnessynge of many a wight
(base) That it was fals that seyde his Aduersarie
(base) This cursed Iuge wolde no thyng tarie
(base) Ne here a word moore of Virginius
(base) But yaf his Iuggement and seyde thus
(base) ¶ I deme anon this cherl his seruant haue
(base) Thou shalt no lenger in thyn hous hir saue
(base) Go bryng hir forth and put hire in oure warde
(base) The cherl shal han his thral this I awarde
(base) ¶ And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
(base) Thurgh sentence of this Iustice Apius
(base) Moste by force his deere doghter yeuen
(base) Vnto the Iuge in lecherie to lyuen
(base) He goth hym hom and sette hym in his halle
(base) And leet anoon his deere doghter calle
(base) And with a face deed as asshen colde
(base) Vpon hir humble face he gan biholde
(base) With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
(base) Al wolde he from his purpos nat conuerte
(base) ¶ Doghter quod he Virginia by thy name
(base) Ther been two weyes outher deeth or shame
(base) That thow most suffre allas that I was bore
(base) For neuere thow deseruedest wherfore
(base) To dyen with a swerd or with a knyf
(base) O deere doghter endere of my lyf
(base) Which I haue fostred vp with swich plesance
(base) That thow were neuere out of my remembrance
(base) O doghter which that art my laste wo
(base) And in my lyf my laste ioye also
(base) O gemme of chastitee in pacience
(base) Tak thow thy deeth for this is my sentence
(base) For loue and nat for hate thow most be deed
(base) My pitous hand moot smyten of thyn heed
(base) Allas that euere Apius thee say
(base) Thus hath he falsly Iugged thee to day
(base) Is there no grace is there no remedie cat
(base) And tolde hire al the cas as ye bifore
(base) Han herd nat nedeth for to telle it moore
(base) ¶ O mercy deere fader quod this mayde
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) And with that word she bothe hir armes layde
(base) Aboute his nekke as she was wont to do
(base) The teeris borste out of hir eyen two
(base) And seyde goode fader shal I dye
(base) Is ther no grace is ther no remedye
(base) ¶ No certes deere doghter myn quod he
(base) ¶ Thanne yif me leyser fader myn quod she
(base) My deeth for to compleyne a litel space
(base) For pardee Iepte yaf his doghter grace
(base) For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
(base) And god it woot no thyng was hir trespas
(base) But for she ran hir fader for to se
(base) To wel come hym with greet solempnytee
(base) And with that word she fil aswowne anon
(base) And after whan hir swownyng is agon
(base) She riseth vp and to hir fader sayde
(base) Blessed be god that I shal dye a mayde
(base) Yif me my deeth er that I haue a shame
(base) Dooth with youre child youre wyl a goddes name
(base) And with that word she preyed hym ful ofte
(base) That with his swerd he wolde smyte softe
(base) And with that word aswowne doun she fil
(base) ¶ Hir fader with ful sorweful herte and wil
(base) Hir heed of smoot and by the top it hente
(base) And to the Iuge he gan it to presente
(base) As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie
(base) ¶ And whan the Iuge it saw as seith the storie
(base) He bad to take hym and anhange hym faste
(base) But right anon a thousand peple In thraste
(base) To saue the knyght for routhe and for pitee
(base) For knowen was the false Iniquitee
(base) ¶ The peple anon hadde suspect in this thyng
(base) By manere of the cherles chalangyng
(base) That it was by the assent of Apius
(base) They wisten wel that he was lecherus
(base) For which vnto this Apius they gon
(base) And caste hym in a prison right anon
(base) Ther as he slow hymself and Claudius
(base) That seruant was vnto this Apius
(base) Was demed for to hange vpon a tree
(base) But that Virginius of his pitee
(base) So preyde for hym that he was exiled
(base) And ellis certes he hadde been bigyled
(base) The remenant were anhanged moore and lesse
(base) That were consentant of this cursednesse
(base) ¶ Heere may men seen how synne hath his merite
(base) Beth war for no man woot whom god wol smyte
(base) In no degree ne in which manere wise
(base) The worm of conscience may agrise
(base) Of wikked lyf thogh it so pryuee be
(base) That no man woot ther of but god and he
(base) For be he lewed man or ellis lered
(base) He noot how soone that he shal been afered
(base) Therfore I rede yow this conseil take
(base) Forsaketh synne er synne yow forsake
(base) ¶ Here endeth the Phisiciens tale
(base) ¶The myry talkyng of the hoost to the Phisicien and the Pardoner
(base) Et Incipit Prologus de la Pardoner cum fabula sua .
(base) Oure hoost gan to swere / as he were wood
(base) Harrow quod he / by nayles and by blood
(base) This was a fals cherl / and a fals Iustise
(base) As shameful deeth / as herte may deuyse
(base) Come to thise Iuges / and hir Aduocatz
(base) So falle vpon his body and his bones
(base) Algate this sely mayde / is slayn allas
(base) Þe deuyl I bekenne him al at ones
(base) Allas / to deere boghte she beautee
(base) Wherfore I seye alday / that men may se
(base) That yiftes of Fortune / and of nature
(base) Been cause of deeth / to many a creature
(base) Of bothe yiftes / that I speke of now

div.l: (base) But her of wil I not ꝓprocede as now
(base) Hir beaute was hir deþ I dar wel sayn
(base) Men han ful ofte / moore for harm than prow
(base) Hir beaute was hir deth I dar wel sayn
(base) Allas so pitously as she was slayn
(base) ¶ But trewely / myn owene maister deere
(base) This is a pitous tale / for to heere
(base) But nathelees passe ouer is no fors
(base) I pray to god / so saue thy gentil cors
(base) And eek thyne vrynals / and thy Iurdones
(base) Thyn Ypocras / and eek thy galyones
(base) And euery boyste / ful of thy letuarie
(base) God blesse hem / and oure lady Seinte Marie
(base) So mote I then / thow art a propre man
(base) And lyk a prelat / by Seint Ronyan
(base) Seyde I nat wel / I kan nat speke in terme
(base) But wel I woot thow doost myn herte to erme
(base) That I almoost haue caught a Cardynacle
(base) By corpus bones / but if I haue triacle
(base) Or ellis a draghte / of moyste and corny ale
(base) Or but I heere anon / a murye tale
(base) Myn herte is lost for pitee of this mayde
(base) ¶ Thow beel amy / thow Pardoner he sayde
(base) Tel vs som myrthe / or Iapes right anon
(base) ¶ It shal be doon quod he / by Seint Ronyon
(base) But first quod he / heere at this ale stake
(base) I wol bothe drynke / and eten of a Cake
(base) ¶ And right anon / thise gentils gonne to crye
(base) Nay lat hym telle vs / of no ribawdye
(base) Tel vs som moral thyng / that we may leere
(base) Som wit / and thanne wol we gladly heere
(base) ¶ Gladly quod he and seide as ye shal here
(base) But in the cuppe wol I me bithinke
(base) ¶ I graunte ywis quod he / but I moot thynke
(base) Vpon som honeste thyng whil that I drynke
(base) Here endeth the reheytyng of our hoost
(base) Radix omnium malorum est cupiditas
Here begynneth the pardoners tale
Lordynges quod he in a chirche when I preche
I peyne me tohave an hauten speche
I ryng it oute as rounde as dothe a bel
For I can al be root that I tel
teeme is alway on and evir was
Radix omnium malarum est cupiditas
Ferst I pronounce whens that I come
And than my bulles shewe al and som
Oure liege lordes seale on my patent
That shew I ferst my bodi to warant
That no man be so boolt preest ne clerke
Me to distourbe of Cristes holi werke
And aftir that tel I forth my tales
Bullos of popes and of cardinales
Of patriarches and of bishopes I shewe
And in latyn I speke wordes a fewe
To savere with my predicacion
And forto stere men to devocion
Than shew I forth my longe cristal stones
I crammed ful of clovtes and of bones
Reliqes thei be as wene thei ilbon
Than haue I in laton a sholder boon
Which that was of an holy Iewes shepe
Good men say I take to my wordes kepe
If that this boon be washen in a wel
If cow or calf shepe or ox swel
That eny worme hathe ete or stvng
Aboute the herte or elles the lung
And it is hole anon and ferthermore
Of pokkes of skab and of eueri sore
Shal everi shepe be hool that of this wel
Drynkith a draught take hede what I tel
If that the good man that the beest oweth
Wil everi dai er that the cok croweth
Fastyng drynk of this wel a draught
As thilke holy Iew oure elders taught
His beestes and his store shal multiply
And seres it heleth also Ielesy
And thogh a man be fallen in Ielosi rage
Lete make with this water his potage
And nevir shal he his wif mystrist
Thogh he the sothe of hir defaute wist ¶
Al had she take a preest ye two or thre
Here is a medicyne eke that ye may see
He that his honde wil put in this metayn
He shal haue multiplyyng of his greyn
When he hathe sowen be it whete or otes
So that he bryng me good pens or grotes
And men and women othyng I warne yow
If eny wight be in this chirche now
That hathe do syn orible that he
Dar not for shame of it shreven be
Or eny woman be she yonge or olde
That hathe made hir husbonde cokwolde
Soche folke shal haue no power ne no grace
To offre to my releqes in this place
And whoso fyndith hym oute of soche blame
And thei wil come vp and offre in goddes name
And I assoile hem be the auctorite
Soche as my bul was grauntid to me
Be this gavde haue I won everi yere
An hundred marke sith I was pardoner
I stonde like a clerk in my pulpett
And shewe lewde peple and syn I sit
I preche so as I haue herde before
And tel an hundred iapes more
Then peyne I me to streche forth the nek
And Eest and weste vpon the peple I bek
As dothe a dovve sittyng vpon a berne
My hondes and my tung goon ful yerne
That it is ioy to see my besynes
Of averice and soche cursednes
Is al my prechyng forto make hem free
To yeve her pens and nameli vnto me
For myne entent is not bot forto wyn
And no thyng for corecciou of syn
I rek nevir when that thei be beried
Thogh her soules gon on blakberied
For certes many a predicaciou
Cometh oft tyme of evil entenciou
Some of plesaunce of folke and of flateri
To be avaunted be ypocracy
And som be veynglori and for hate
For when I dar not other weies debate
Then wil I styng hem with my tung smert
In prechyng so that he shal not stert
To be defamed falsely so that he
Hathe trespaced to my brethryn or to me
For thogh I tel not his propre name
Men shal wel knowe that it is the same
Be som signe and othir circomstaunces
Thus spit I oute my venym vnder hew
Of holynes to som men holy and trew
Bot shortly myne entent I wil devise
I preche of nothyng bot of covetise
Therfore my teme is yit and evir was
Radix omnium malarum est cupiditas
Thus can I preche ayenst the same vice
Which that I vse and that is auerise
Bot thogh my self be gilti in that syn
Yit can I make othir folke to wyn
From averice and sore hem repent
Bot that nys not my principal entent
I preche not bot for covetise
Of this mater it aught y nough soffise
Than tel I hem ensamples many oon
Of olde stories longe tyme goon
For lewde peple leven tales olde
Soche thynges can thei reporte and holde
What trowe ye that whiles I may preche
And wyn golde and silver forto teche
That I wil leve in poverte wilfully ¶
Nay nay I thought it nevir trevli
For I wil preche and beg in sondri londes
I wil not do no labore with my hondes
Ne make baskettes ne leve ther by
Be cause I wil not leven Idely
I wil noon of the postles counterfete
I wil haue money malte chese and wheet
Al were it yeven of the porest page
Or of the porest widow in the village
Al sholde her children sterve for famyne
And I wil drinke the licorest of the wyne
And haue a ioly wenche in everi toun
Bot herkenith lordynges in conclusiou
Youre likyng is that I shal tel a tale
Be god I hope I shal tel yow a thyng
That shal be reson be at youre likyng
For thogh my self be a ful viciouse man
Amoral tale yit I yow tel can
Where Iames went to preche soules forto wyn
Now holde youre pees my tale I wil begyn
IN flaundris whilom was a company
Of yonge folke that hauntid foly
As aseerd riot stewes and tavernes
Harpes ribibes lutes and geternes
Thei dauncen and pleyen atte dise night and day
And ete also ovir that her might may
Thorugh which thei do the dewle sacrifice
Within the develes temple in sondri wise
With superfluite abhominable
Her othes be so grete and dampnable
That it is griseli forto here hem swere
Oure blissid lordes bodi thei to tere
Hem thought Iewes rent hym not y nough
And ilke of hem at others syn lough
And right anon come in than tombilsters
Fetise and smale and yong frutrers
Syngers with harpes bawdes and waferers
Soche be verili the devles officers
To kyndle and blowe the fire of lechery
That is a next to goloteny
The holy writ take I to witnes
That lecheri is in wyne and in drunkenes
Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay be his doughters two vnwetyngly
So dronken he was he nist what he wrought
Herodes whoso hath the stories sought
When he of wyne was replete at his feest
Right at his oune table yaf his heest
To slee the baptist Iohn ful giltles
Senek saith a good woorde doutles
He saith he can no difference fynde
Betwixt a man that is oute of his mynde
And a man that is drunkelew
Bot that woodnes fallen in a shrew
Parseverith lenger than dothe drvnkenes
O gloteny ful of cursidnes
O cause ferst of oure confusiou
Origynal of oure dampnaciou
Til Crist had bought vs with his blood agayn
Lo how dere shortely forto seyn
Abought was the cursid vileny
Corupt was al this worlde thorugh gloteny
Adam oure fadir and his wif also
Fro paradise to labore and to woo
Were dreven for that vice it is no drede
For whiles that Adam fastid as I rede
He was in paradise and when that he
Ete of the frute defendid of the tre
Anon he was oute caste to woo and peyne ¶
O gloteny on the wel aught vs to pleyne
O wist aman how many maladies
Foleweth of excesse and of glotenyes
He wolde be the more mesurable
Of his diet sittyng at his table
Allas the shorte trouthe the tender mouthe
Makith that eest and weste northe and southe
In erthe in aiere in water makith men to swynk
To gete a gloton deyntees mete and drynk
Of this mater o poule wel can thou trete
Mete vnto the wombe and wombe eke vnto the mete
Shal god distroy bothe as poule saith
Allas a foule thyng it is be my feith
To say this woorde and fouler is the dede
When men so drynkith of the white and rede
That of his throot he makith his prevey
Thorugh thilk suꝑper/parfluite
The appostil wepyng saith ful pitously
Ther walkith many of which tolde have I
I say it now wepyng with pitouse voise
Ther ben enemyes of Cristes croise
Of which the ende is deth wombe is her good
O wombe o bely o stynkyng cood
Fulfilled of dung and of corupciou
At everi ende of foule is the sesou
How grete coste and labore is to fynde
Thise cokes how thei stampe streyne and grynde
And turne substance into accident
To fulfil al thi labours talent
Oute of the harde bones knok thei
The mary for thei caste not away
That may goo thorugh the golet soft and soot
Of spiceri of leves barke and root
Shal be his sause y made be delite
To make hym yit a newe apetite
Bot certes he that hauntith soche delites
Is dede whiles that he levith in vices
A lecherouse thyng is wyne and dronkones
It is ful of strivyng and wrechednes
O dronken man disfigured in thi face
Foule is thi brethe foule arte thou to enbrace
And thorugh thi drunkun nose sovnith the soun
As thogh thou saidest ay Sampsou Sampsou
And yit god woot Sampson dronke nevir no wyne
Thou fallist as it were a dronkyn swyne
Thi tunge is loste and al thy honest cure
For drunkenes is veri sepulture
Of mannes wit and his discreciou
In whom that drynk hathe domynaciou
He can no counsail kepe it is no drede
Now kepe yow fro the white and fro the rede
Nameli fro the white wyne of lepe
That is to sel in fishstrete and in chepe
This wyne of spayne crepith sotilli
In other wynes growyng fast by
Of which risith soche fumosite
That when a man hath dronken adraught or thre
And wenith that he be at home in chepe
Than is he in spayn right atte toun of lepe
Not at Rochel ne at Burdeux toun
And then wil thei sey Sampson Sampsou
Bot herkenith lordynges oon worde I yov prey
That al the souerayn actes dar I say
Of victories in olde testament
That thorugh veri god omnipotent
Were done in abstynence and in preiere
Lokith the bible and there ye may it lere
Loke Actela the grete conquerour
Died in his slepe with shame and dishonour
Bledyng at his nose in dronkenes
A Capteyn sholde leve in sobirnes ¶
And over al thise avise yov right wel
What was comaundid vnto lamvel
Not Samvel bot lamvel say I
Redith the bible and fynde it expresly
Of wyne yevyng of hem that ar Iustice
No more of this for it may soffice
And now that I have spoken of gloteny
Now wil I defende yov hasardry
Hasarde is veri modir of lesynges
And of disceite cursid forswerynges
Blaspheme of Crist manslaughtir and waast also
Of bacale and of tyme and of ferthermoo
It is repreved and contrari to honoure
Forto be holden a comon hasardour
And ay the heier he is of a state
The more he is holden dissolate
If that a prince vse hasardry
In al gouernaunce and pollecy
He is as be comon opynyou
Holde the lasse in reputaciou
Stilbon that was holde a wise enbassatour
Was sent to Corivth with ful grete honour
Fro Calydon to make hem alliaunce
And when he come happid this chaunce
That al the grettest that were of that londe
Pleyyng atte hasarde he hem fonde
For which as sone as that might be
He stale hym home ayen to his cvntre
And saide there I wolde not lose my name
I wolde not take on me so grete defame
Forto alye yow to non hasardours
Sendith othir wiser enbassatours
For be my trouthe me were lever dey
Than I sholde yow to hasardours ally
For ye that be so gloriouse in honours
Shal not ally yow with hasardours
As be my wil ne as be my trete
This wise philosophre thus saide he
Loke eke that the kyng Emetrevs
The kyng of perces as the boke saith thus
Sent hym a peire of dise of golde in scorne
For he had vsed hasardri ther beforne
For which he helde his glory and his renoun
For no valev of reputaciou
Lordes might fynde othir maner play
Honest ynough to drive the day away
Now wil I speke of othes false and grete
A woorde or two as othir bokes entrete
Grete sweryng is a thyng abhominable
And fals sweryng is moche more reprovable
The hihe god forbad sweryng a al
Witnes of mathew bot in special
Of sweryng the holy Ieromye
Thou shalt swere sothe thyne othes and not ly
And swere in dome and eke in rightwisnes
Bot Idel sweryng is a cursidnes
Beholde and see that in the ferst table
Of hihe godes heestes honorable
How tw heestes of hym is this
Take not my name in idelnes amys
Lo rathir he forbede soche sweryng
Than homicide er eny othir thyng
I say as thus be ordre it stondith
This knoweth that his heestes vnderstondith
How that the second heest of god is that
And ferther ovir I wil tel al plat
That vengeance shal not parte fro his house
That of his othes is so outrageous
Be godes preciouse herte and his nailes ¶
And be his blood that is in hayles
Seven is my chaunche and his five and thre
Be godes armes if thou falseli pley me
This dager shal thorugh thyn herte goo
This frute comyth of thilk bones twoo
Forsweryng Ire falsenes homicide
Now for the love of Criste that for vs deide
Leveth youre othes bothe grete and smale
For I shal tel a mervelouse tale
Thise riotours of which I tel
Longe erst or pryme ronge eny bel
Were set in ataverne to drynk
And as thei sat thei herde a bel clynk
Before a corps was caried to the grave
That on of hem gan cal to his knave
Go bet quod he and aske redili
What corps is that passith forbi
And loke that thou reporte his name wel
Sir quod this knave it nedith nevir adel
It was me tolde er ye come here two oures
He was parde an olde felaw of youres
Al sodeynly was he slayne to night
Fordronken as he sat vpon his benche vpright
Ther come a prive theef men clepe deth
That in his cuntre al peple sleeth
And with his spere he smote his herte atwo
And went his way withoute wordes moo
He hath a thousand slayn this pestilence
And maister er ye come in presence
Me thynkith it were necessary
Forto be war of soche an aduersary
Beth redi forto mete hym evir more
Thus taught me my dame I say no more
Be seynt mary saide this taverner
The childe saith sothe for he hathe slayn to yere
Hennes ouer amyle within a grete village
Bothe man and woman childe and page
I trow his habitacion be there
To be avised grete wisdome it were
Or that he did a man dishonour
Ye goddes armes quod this riatour
Is it soche peril with hym forto mete
I shal hym seche be sty and be strete
I make avow be the digne goddes bones
Herkenith felawes we thre be al ones
Late iche of vs holde vp his honde til othir
And ich of vs become othres brothir
And we wil slee this fals traitore deth
He shal be slayn he that so many sleeth
Be godes dignite or it be night
To gidre haue thise thre her trouthe plight
To leve and to die ilke of hem with othir
As thogh he were his oune borne brothir
And vp thei sterten and drynkyn in this rage
And forthe thei gone towarde that village
Of which the taverner hath spoke before
And many a griseli othe than haue thei swore
And cristes blissed bodi thei to rent
That dede shal be dethe if thei may hym hent
When thei haue gone not fulli a myle
Right as thei wolde haue troden ouer a stile
An olde and a pore man with hem met
This olde man ful mekeli hem gret
And saide thus now lordes god yow see
The proudest of thise riatours thre
Answered ayen what cherle with hardi grace
Whi arte thou al for wrapped save thi face
Why levest thou so longe in so grete age
This olde man gan loke in his visage ¶
And saide thus for I can not fynde
Aman thogh I walked into Inde
Ner in cite ne in no village
That wil changen his youth for myne age
And therfore mote I haue myne age stil
As longe tyme as it is goddes wil
Ne deth llas wilnot haue my lif
Thus walke I aresteles caitif
And on the grounde which is my modir gate
I knok with my staf erly and late
And say leve modir late me yn
Lo how I vanysh flesh and blood and skyn
Allas when shal my bones be at reste
Moder with yow wolde I change my cheste
That in my chambre longe tyme hathe be
Ye for an here cloute to wrap me
Bot yit to me she wil not do that grace
For which ful whelkid is my face
Bot sires to yow it is no courtesi
To speke vntil an olde man vileny
Bot he trespace in woorde or elles in dede
In holy writ ye may youre self wel rede
Ayenst an olde man hore vpon his hede
Ye shal arise therfore I yeve yov rede
Ne dothe vntil an olde man harme as now
No more than ye wolde a man did to yow
In age if that ye so longe abide
And god be with yow whethir ye goo or ride
I moot goo thider as I haue to goo
Nay olde cherle be god thou shalt not soo
Saide this othir hasardour anon
Thou partist not so lightly be seynt Iohn
Thou spake right now of that ilke traitore deth
That in this cuntre al oure frendes sleeth
Haue here my trouthe as thou arte his aspy
Tel where he is or elles thou shalt dey
Be god and be the holy sacrament
For sotheli thou arte of his assent
To sleen vs yong folke thou false theef
Now seres if it be to yow leef
To fynde dethe turne vp this croked way
For in that grove I laft hym be my fay
Vnder a tre and ther he wil abide
Ne for your boost he wil hym nothyng hide
Se ye that oke right there ye shal hym fynde
God save yov that bought ayen mankynde
And yov amende thus saide this olde man
And everich of thise riatours ran
Til thei come to the tre and there thei fonde
Floreyns of golde fyne y coyned rounde
Welnigh a seven bushel as hem thought
No lengir than aftir deth thei sought
Bot iche of hem so glad was of that sight
For that the floreyns so faire were and bright
That doun thei set hem be that preciouse hoord
The werst of hem he spak the ferst woord
Brethren quod he take hede what I say
Mi wit is grete thogh I boorde and play
This tresore hathe fortune til vs yeven
In mirthe and iolite oure lif to leven
And lightli so as it comyth so wil we spende
A presiouse goddes herte who wende
To day that we sholde haue so faire a grace
Bot might this golde be caried fro this place
Home vnto my house or elles to youres
For wel I woot that al this golde is oures
Then were we in hihe felicite ¶
Bot treuli be day it may not be
Men wolde sey that we were theves strong
And for oure oune tresor done vs hong
As wiseli and as sleli as it might
This tresore moste y caried be by night
Wherfore I rede lat loke amonges al
To drawe and lat se where the cut wil fal
He that hathe the cut with herte blithe
Shal ren to toun and that ful swithe
To bryng vs brede and drynk ful preveli
And two of vs shal kepen ful sotilli
This tresore wel and if he wil not tary
When it is night we wil this tresore cary
Be oon assent where as vs likith best
That on of hem brought grasse in his fist
And bad hem drawe and loke on whom it wolde fal
And it fel on the yongest of hem al
And forthe towarde the toune he went anon
And also sone as he was gone
That oon of hem spak vnto that othir
Thou woost wel thou arte myne oune sworn brothir
Thi profite wil I tel the anon
Thou woost wel that oure felaw is goon
And here is golde and that right grete plente
That it shal departid be amonge vs thre
Bot netheles If I can shape it so
That it departid were amonge vs two
Had I not done a freendes torne to the
That other answered I note how that might be
I wolde wel that the golde were oures two
What sholde we do that it might be soo
Shal it be counsail saide the ferst shrewe
And I shal tel in wordes fewe
What we shal done and bryng it aboute
I graunte quod the othir oute of doute
That be my trouthe I wil the not be wreien
Now quod this ferst thou woost wel we be tweyn
And two of vs shal strenger be than on
Loke when he is set and that anon
Arise as thogh thou woldest with hym play
And I shal riven hym thorugh the sides twey
Whiles thou stroglest with hym as in game
And with thi dagger loke thou do the same
And than shal this golde departid be
Mi dere freende betwixt the and me
Than may we bothe oure lustes fulfil
And pley atte deise right at oure oune wil
And thus accorded be thise shrewes twey
To sle the thrid if ᵗheⁱ may
This yongest which that went to the toun
Fuloft in his herte he rolled vp and doun
The beaute of thise floreyns faire and bright
O lorde quod he if it so were I might
Have al this tresore to miself allon
Ther is no man that levith vndir trone
Of golde that sholde leve as meri as I
And atte laste the feende oure enemy
Put in his thought that he sholde poyson by
With which he might sleen his felawes twey
For whi the feende fonde hym in soche levyng
That he had leve hym to sorew bryng
For this was vtterli his entent
And to slen hem bothe and nevir to repent
And forth he gothe no lenger wolde he tary
Into the toun vnto a potecary
And preied hym that he hym wolde sel
Som poison that he might his rattes kil
And eke ther was a polcat in his hawe
That as he saide his capons had y slawe ¶
And saide he wolde wreke hym if he might
Of vermyn that distroied hym be night
The potecari answered thou shalt haue
A thyng that als god my soule save
In al this worlde ther nys no creature
That ete or drynke of this confecture
Not bot the mountaunce of a corne of whete
That he ne shal his lif anon forlete
Ye sterve he shal and that in lasse while
Than thou wilt gone a pace nought bot amyle
This poison that is so harde and violent
This cursid man hath in his honde hent
This poison in a box and sethens he ran
Into the next strete vnto a man
And borewed hym large botels thre
To his felawes a yen repaireth he
The thrid he kept clene for his drynk
For al the night he shope hym to swynk
In caryyng of that golde oute of that place
And when this riator with sory grace
Had filled with hym his grete botels thre
To his felawes ayen repaired he
What nedith it to sermon therof more
For right as thei had caste his deth before
Right so thei haue hym slayn and that anon
And when this was don than spake that on
Now late vs sit and drynk and make vs mery
And aftirwarde we wil his bodi bery
And aftir that it happed hem per caas
To take a botel wher in the poison was
And dranke and yaf his felaw drynk also
Thorugh which a non thei sterven bothe two
Bot certes I suppose that Avicen
Wroot nevir in no canon ne in no fen
Moo wondir sorowes of enpoisenyng
Thus had thise wreches two her endyng
Thus endid be thise homycides two
And eke this fals empoisener also
O cursid syn ful of al cursidnes
O traitours homicides o wikkednes
O glotony lecheri and hasardri
Thou blasphemer of crist with vileny
And othes grete of vsage and of pride
Allas mankynde how may it betide
That to the creatour which that the wrought
And with his preciouse blood the bought
Thou arte so fals and so vnkynde allas
Now good god foryeve yow youre trespas
And kepe yov fro the syn of auerice
My holy pardon may yov al warish
So that ye offer nobles or sterlynges
Or elles silver spones broches or rynges
Bow youre hed vndir this bul
Come vp ye wyves offre youre wol
Youre names I entre here in my rol anon
Into the blis of heven shal ye al goon
I yov assoile be my hihe povere
Ye that wil offre as clene and eke as clere
As ye were borne and lo sirs thus I preche
And Ihıı̄un Crist that is oure soules leche
So graunte yow this pardon to receyve
For that is best I wil not yow disceyve
Bot sirs oon worde forgate I in my tale
I have reliqes and pardon in my male
As faire as eny man in Englond
Which were yeve me be the popes honde
If eny of yow wil of devociou
Offer and have myne absoluciou
Come forth anon and knelith here adoun
That ye may have parte of my pardou
Or elles take pardon as ye wend
Al newe and fresh at everi tounes ende
So that ye offre al way newe and newe ¶¶
Nobles and pens which that be good and trewe
It is an honour euer to yow that be here
That ye haue a soffisaunt pardoner
To assoile you in contre as ye ride
For aventurs which that may betide
For parauenture ye may fal oon or two
Doun of his horse and breke his nek atwo
Loke soche a seurte it is to you al
That I am in youre feleship y fal
That may assoile yow bothe more and lesse
When that the soule shal fro the bodi passe
I rede that youre self begyn
For he is mooste involupt with syn
Come forth oure oste and offre ferst anon
And thou shalte kis the reliques everichoon
¶ Ye for a groot vnbokil anon the purs
Nay nay quod he than haue I Cristes curse
Lat be quod he it shal not be so theich
Thou woldest make me kis thyn olde breche
Thogh it were with thi fundament peynt
And swere it were the relike of a seynt
Bot be the crosse which seint Eleyn fonde
I wolde I had thyn colyons in my honde
In stede of reliqes be seint mary
Late cut hem of and I wil helpe hem cary
Thei sholde be streyned in a whip corde
This pardoner answered not oon woorde
So wrothe he was he wolde no worde say
Now quod oure oste I wil no lenger play
With the ne with non othir angry man
Bot right anon the worthi knight be gan
When that he saugh that al the peple lough
Nomore of this for here is right y nough
Sir pardoner be mery and glad of chere
And ye sir ooste that be to me so dere
I prey yow that ye kis the pardoner
And pardoner I prey yow draw yow ner
And as we did late vs laugh and play
And anon thei kist and reden forth her way
Here endith the pardons tale and here

nOW frendis seid oure host so dere
Hough likith you by Iohn þe ꝑper/pardoner̉er/re
For he hath vnboclid wel þe male
He hath no tolde right A thryfty tale
As touching as of mysgouernaunce
I pray to god yeve hym right good chaunce
As ye haue herd of thees Riotours thre
Now gentle Maryner hertily pray I thee
Telle us a . good tale . ⁊and that right anon
It shalbe done by god and by seint Iohn
Seid the Maryner as wel as eủer/re I . can
And right anone his tale he beganne

div.l: (base) Thanne moot another payen for oure cost
(base) Or lene vs gold and that is perilous
(base) This noble Marchant heeld a worthy hous
(base) For which he hadde alday so greet repair
(base) For his largesse and for his wyf was fair
(base) That wonder is but herkneth to my tale
(base) Amonges alle hise gestes grete and smale
(base) Ther was a Monk a fair man and a bold
(base) I trowe a thritty wynter he was old
(base) That euere in oon was drawyng to that place
(base) This yonge Monk that was so fair of face
(base) Aqueynted was so with the goode man
(base) Sith that hir firste knewliche bigan
(base) That in his hous as famulier was he
(base) As it is possible any freend to be
(base) And for as muchel as this goode man
(base) And eek this Monk of which that I bigan
(base) Were bothe two yborn in o village
(base) The Monk hym claymeth as for cosynage
(base) And he agayn he seith nat ones nay
(base) But was as glad ther of as fowel of day
(base) For to his herte it was a gret plesance
(base) Thus been they knyt with eterne alliance
(base) And ech of hem gan oother for tassure
(base) Of bretherhede whil that hir lyf may dure
(base) Free was daun Iohn and manly of dispence
(base) As in that hous and ful of diligence
(base) To doon plesance and also greet costage
(base) He nat forgat to yeue the leeste page
(base) In al that hous but after hir degree
(base) He yaf the lord and sith al his meynee
(base) Whan that he cam som manere honeste thyng
(base) For which they were as glad of his comyng
(base) As fowel is fayn whan that the sonne vp riseth
(base) Namoore of this as now for it suffiseth
(base) But so bifel this Marchant on a day
(base) Shoop hym to make redy his array
(base) Toward the town of Brugges for to fare
(base) To byen there a porcion of ware
(base) For which he hath to Parys sent anon
(base) A messager and preyed hath daun Iohn
(base) That he sholde come to Seint Denys and pleye
(base) With hym and with his wyf a day or tweye
(base) Er he to Brugges wente in alle wise
(base) This noble Monk of which I yow deuyse
(base) Hath of his Abbot as hym list licence
(base) By cause he was a man of heigh prudence
(base) And eek an Officer out for to ryde
(base) To seen hir granges and hir bernes wyde
(base) And vnto Seint Denys he comth anon
(base) Who was so welcome as my lord Daun Iohn
(base) Oure deere cosyn ful of curteisye
(base) With hym broghte he a Iubbe of Maluesye
(base) And eek another ful of fyn vernage
(base) And volatil as ay was his vsage
(base) And thus I lete hem ete and drynke and pleye
(base) This Marchant and this Monk a day or tweye
(base) The thridde day this Marchant vp ariseth
(base) And on his nedes sadly hym auyseth
(base) And vp into his Countour hous goth he
(base) To rekene with hymself wel may be
(base) Of thilke yeer how that it with hym stood
(base) And how that he despended hadde his good
(base) And if that he encressed were or noon
(base) Hise bokes and his bagges many oon
(base) He leyth biforn hym on his Countyng bord
(base) Ful riche was his tresor and his hord

(base) And thus he sit til it was passed prime
(base) Daun Iohn was risen in the morwe also

(base) and therfore I
pray yow that in this necessitee and in this nede ye caste yow to ouercome youre herte

(base) For Senek seith that he that ouercometh his herte
ouercometh twies

(base) And Tullius seith ther is no thyng so commendable
in a greet lord

(base) as whan he is debonaire and meke and apeiseth hym
lightly
(base) And I pray yow that ye wol forbere now to do vengeance
(base) in swich a manere that youre good name may be kept and conserued

(base) and that men mowe haue cause and matere to preise yow of
pitee and of mercy

(base) and that ye haue no cause to repente yow of thyng
that ye doon

(base) For Senek seith he ouercometh in an yuel manere
that repenteth hym of his victorie

(base) Wherfore I prey yow lat mercy
be in youre herte

(base) to theffect and entente that god almyghty haue merci
on yow in his laste Iugement

(base) For Seint Iame seith in his epistle
Iugement with oute mercy shal be doon to hym that hath no mercy of
another wight

(base) Whanne Melibe hadde herd the grete skiles
and resons of dame Prudence and hir wise Informaciouns and techynges
(base) his herte gan enclyne to the wyl of his wyf considerynge hir trewe entente

(base) conformed hym anon and assented
fully to werken after hir conseil
(base) and thonked god of whom procedeth al vertu and al goodnesse that hym sente a wyf of so greet discrecoun

(base) And whanne the day cam that hise Aduersaries sholde appieren
in his presence
(base) he spak to hem ful goodly and seyde in this wise

(base) Al be it so that of youre pride and by presumpcioun and folie and of youre
necligence and vnkonnynge

(base) ye haue mysborn yow and trespased
vn to me
(base) yet for as muchel as I se and biholde youre grete humylitee
(base) and that ye been sory and repentant of youre giltes
(base) it constreyneth me to do yow grace and mercy

(base) Wherfore I receyue yow
to my grace
(base) and foryeue yow outrely alle the offenses Iniuries and wronges that ye haue doon ageyns me and myne

(base) to this
effect and to this ende that god of his endelees mercy

(base) wole atte
tyme of oure dyynge foryeuen vs oure giltes that we han
trespassed to hym in this wrecched world

(base) for doutelees if
we be sory and repentant of the synnes and giltes whiche we
han trespased in the sighte of oure lord god

(base) he is so free
and so merciable
(base) that he wole foryeuen vs oure giltes
(base) and bryngen vs to the blisse that neuere hath ende
(base) Here is endid Chaucers tale of Melibe

div.l: When ended was the tale of mellibe
And of prudence and of hir benignite
Oure oost saide as I am feithful man
And be the precious corpus Madrian
I had levere than a barel of ale
That goodleef my wif had herde this tale
For she nys nothyng of soche pacience
As was this Mellibeus wif prudens
Be goddes bones when I bete my knaves
She bryngeth me the grete clobbed staves
And crieth slee the dogges everichoon
And breke bothe bak and boon
And if eny neighborew of myne
Wil not in chirche to my wif enclyne
Or be so hardi to hir to trespas
When she comith home she rampith in my face
And crieth fals cowarde wreke thi wif
Be corpus bonus I wil haue thi knif
And thou shalt haue my distaf and go spyn
Fro day til night right thus she wil begyn
Allas she saith that ever was I shape
To wed a melkesop or a cowarde ape
That wil be ouer lad with everi wight
Thou darst not stonde be thi wif a right
This is my lif but if that I wolde feight
And oute atte dore anon I mote me dight
Or elles I am loste bot if that I
Be like a wilde lyon fole hardi
I woot wel she wil do me slee som day
Som neighborugh and than go my way
For I am ꝑper/parilous with knif in honde
Al be it so I dar not with hir stonde
For she is big in arme be my feith
That shal be fynde that hir mysdoth or saith
Bot lat vs passe a wey fro this mater
Mi lorde sir monke he saith be meri of chere
For ye shal tel a tale trevly
Lo Rowchestir stant here fast by
Ride forth myne oune lorde breke not our game
Bot be my trouthe I knowe not youre name
Wher I shal cal yov my lorde dan Iohn
Or dan thomas or dan Albyon
Of what house be ye be youre fadir kyn
I vowe to god thou haste a ful bare skyn
It is a gentil pasture there thou goost
Thou arte not like a penant or a goost
Vpon my feith thou arte som officer
Som worthi Segestyn or som Seleyer
For be my fadir soule as to my dome
Thou arte a maister whan thou arte at home
No pore cloistreye ne no pore novise
Bot a governour wili and wise
And ther with al of brawnes and of bones
A wel faryng person for the nones
I prey to god yif hym confusiou
That ferst the brought into religiou
Thou woldest have be a tredyng foule of right
Haddest thou as grete leve as thou hast might
To par fourme al thi luste in engendrure
Thou haddeste begoten many a creature
Allas whi werest thou so wide a cope
God yif me sorew and I were a pope
Not oneli thou bot everi mighti man
Thogh he were shore hihe vpon his pan
Sholde have a wif for al the worlde is lorne
Religion hath take vp al the corne
Of tredyng and we borel men be shrympes
Of feble trees ther cometh wreched ympes
This makith that oure heires be so sklendir
And feble that thei may not wel engendre
This makith that oure wives wil assay
Religous folke for thei may bettir pay
Of venus paiement then mowe we
God woot as lushboornes pay ye
Bot beth not wrothe my lorde thogh that I play
Ful oft in my game a sothe I have herde sey
This worthi munke toke al in pacience
And saide I wil do al my diligence
As serforth as seineth into honeste
To tel yow a tale or two or thre
And if yow list herkenith hiderwarde
I wil yow seyn the lif of seynt Edwarde
Or elles tregedis ferst wil I tel
Of which I have an hundred in my sel
Yit to tel a certayn story a
As olde bokes make memori
Of hem that stood in grete prosperite
And is y fal oute of hihe degre
Into myseri and endith wikkedli
And thei be vercified comonli
Of six feet which that man clepe exhantren
In prose eke be enditid many oon
And eke in meter in many a sondri wise
Lo this aright yow y nough soffise
Now herkenith if you list forto here
Bot ferst I yov besoche in this matere
Thogh I be ordre tel not thise thynges
Be it of popes Emꝑper/parours or kynges
And aftir her ages as men wreten fynde
Bot tel hem som before and som behynde
As it may come to my remembraunce
I haue me excused of myn ignorance
Here begynneth the monkes tale
I Wil be waile in maner of a tregedri
The harme of hem that stonde in degre hihe
And fallen so that ther is no remedi
To bringe hem oute of her aduersite
For certayn when that fortune lust to flee
Ther may no man of hir the cours witholde
Be war be thise ensamples yonge and olde
¶ At lucifer thogh he an angel were
And not a man at hym I wil begyn
For thogh fortune may non angil dere
Fro hihe degre yit fel he for his syn
Doun into hel where he yit is in
O lucifer brightest of angelis al
Now arte thou sathanas that maist not twyn
Oute of miseri in whixh thou arte fal in
¶ Lo Adam in the feelde of damecene
With godes oune fyngers wrought was he
And not be getyng of mannes sperme vnclene
And welt al paradis savyng oon tree
Had never worldli man so hihe degre
As Adam til he for his governaunce
Was dreve oute of prosperite
To labore and to hel and to myschaunce
¶ Lo Sampson which was anucient
Be the angil longe or his natiuite
And was to god almighti consecrat
And stood in noblesse whiles he might see
Was nevir soche anothir as was she
To speke of strengh and therto of hardynes
Bit to his wives tolde he his secre
Thorugh which he slowe hymself with wrechednes
¶ Sampson this noble and mighti champion
Withouten wepen save his hondes twey
He slowe and al torent the lion
Thorugh his weddyng walkyng be the way
His fals wife coude hym so plees and prey
Til she his counsail knewe and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos his counsail gan she wrey
And hym forsoke and toke anothir newe
¶ And hundred foxes toke sampson for ire
And al her tailes he to gider bonde
And set the fox tailes al on fire
For he in everi taile ahd put a bronde
And thei brent al the cornes in that londe /
were I go I to ped
And al her elmes and her vynes eke
A thousand men eke he slowe with his hande
And had no wepen bot an asse cheke boon
¶ When thei were slayn so therstid hym that he
Was wel nigh lore for which he gan to prey
That god wolde of his peyne have som pite
And sende hym drynk or elles moste he dey
And of his Asse cheke that was so dry
¶ Oute of a wange tothe anon spronge a wel
Of which he dranke y nough shortly to sey
Thus helped hym god as iudicum can tel
¶ Be veri force atte Gason on anight
Mavgre philistience of that Cite
The gate of the toun he hath vpplight
And on his bak y caried hem hathe he
Hihe on an hil wher as men might see
O noble and mighti sampson levere and dere
That strong and noble hathe be
In al this worlde ne had ther be thi pere
¶ This sampson nethir sithir drronk ne wyne
Ne on his hed come rasore ne sher
Be precept of the messenger diuine
For al his strengh was in his here
And fulli twenti yere be yere
He had of israel the governaunce
Bot aftir sone shal he wexe many atere
For women shal bryng hym to myschaunce
¶ Vnto his lemman dalida he tolde
That in his hers al his strengh lay
And falseli to his fomen she hym solde
And slepyng vpon her barme vpon a day
She made to clip or shere his here away
And made his fomen al his craft aspien
And when that thei hym fonde in soche aray
Thei bonde hym faste and put oute his yhen
¶ Bot er his here was y clippid or i shave
Ther was no bande that might hym bynde
Bot now is he in prison like aknave
Where as thei made hym atte querne grynde
O noble sampson strengest of mankynde
O whilom yonge in glori and riches
Now maisre thou wepe with thyn yhen blynde
Sith thou arte fro welthe fal into wrechednes
¶ The ende of thise caitifs was as I shal sey
His fomen made a feest vpon a day
And made hym as her fole before hem play
And this was atte temple of a grete aray
But atte laste he made afoule a fray
For he two postes shoke and made hem fal
And doun fel the temple and al there it lay
And slowe hymself and eke his fomen al
¶ This is to sey the prynces euerichoon
And eke a thousande ladies were there slayn
With fallyng of the grete temple of stoon
Of Sampson ne wil I no more sayn
Beth war of thise ensamples olde and pleyn
That no men tel her counsel of her wives
Of soche thynges as thei wolde have secre fayn
If that it touche her lemes or her lyves
¶ Of hercules the soverayn conquerour
Whos werkes did and hihe renoun
For in his tyme of strengh he bare the flour
He slowe and raft the skyn fro the lyon
He of seyntaurus leide the beest adoun
He harpies slowe the crevel brides fel
He golden apples raft the dragon
¶ He drowe oute serbores the hounde of hel
He slowe the crwel tirant buserus
And made his horse to frete his flesh and boon
He slowe the veri serpent venemous
Of Achilles two hornes brake he oon
And he slowe Cacus in a cave of stoon
He slowe the geant Antheus the stronge
He slowe the griseli bore and that anon
As for that night departe company
And ich of hem goth into his hostelery
And toke his loggyng as it wolde fal
That on of hem was loged in a stal
Fer in ayerde with oxen of the plough
That other man was loged wel y nough
As was his aventure or his fortune
That vs governeth al as in comune
And so be fel longe or it were day
This man met in his bed there he lay
How that his felaw gan on hym cal
And saide allas for in an ox stal
This night shal I be murthrid ther I ly
Now helpe my dere brothir or I dey
In al haste come to me he saide
This man oute of his slepe for fere he braide
Bot when that he was wakened oute of his slepe
He tvrned hym and toke of this no kepe
Hym thought his dreme was nought bot vanite
Thus twies in his slepyng dremed he
And atte thrid tyme yet his felawe
Saide as hym thought I am now slawe
Beholde my blody woundes depe and wide
Arise vp erly in the morew tide
And atte weste gate of the toun quod he
A cartful of dunge there shalt thou see
In which my bodi is hid ful preveli
Doo thilk carte areste boldely
My golde caused my murthir sothe to seyn
And tolde hym everi poynt how he was slayn
With a ful pitous face pale of hewe
And trist wel his dreme he fande ful trewe
For on the morew as sone as it was day
To his felawes in he toke the way
And when he come to the ox stal
Aftir his felaw he gan to cal
The hosteler answered hym anon
And saide sir youre felaw is goon
As sone as it was day he wente oute of the toun
This man gan fal in grete suspecciou
Remembryng on his dreme that he mett
And forth he goth no lenger wolde he lett
Vnto the west gate of the toun and fonde
A dunge carte as he wente to dunge the londe
That was arayed in the same wise
As ye have herde the dede man devise
And with an hardi herte he gan to cry
Vegeance and iustice on this vileny
Mi felaw mvrthrid is this same night
And in this carte he lieth gapyng vpright
The dede man that mvrthrid was al new
O blisful god that arte so iuste and trewe
Lo how that thou wreiest mvrthir alway
Murthir wil oute that se we day be day
Mvrthir is lothesom and abhomynable
To god that is so iuste and resonable
Than he ne wil not soffre it heled be
Thogh it abide ayere ot two or thre
Mvrthir wil oute this is my conclusion
And right anon mynystres of the toun
Have hent the carter and sore hym peyned
And eke the osteler so was engined
That thei be knewe her wikkidnes anon
And were hanged be the nek boon
Here may men see that dremes be to drede
And certes in the same boke I rede
Right in the next chaptir I rede of this
I gab not so have I ioy or blis
Two men that woldhave passid the see
For certayn causes into a fer contre
If that the wynde ne had be contrari
For that made hem in a cite forto tari
That stood ful mery vpon the haven side ¶the
Bot on aday a yenst the even tide
The wynde gan change and blewe as hym list
Ioli and glad thei went vnto reste
And casten hem ful erly forto saile
Bot herkenyth that on man fel in grete ꝑper/paril
That oon of hem in slepyng as he lay
Hym met a wonder dreme ayenst the day
Hym thought a man stood be his bed side
And hym comaundid that he sholde abide
And saide hym thus if thou to morne wende
Thou shalt be drenched my tale is atta ende
He woke and tolde his felow what he met
And preied hym his viage forto let
As for that day he preied hym forto abide
His felow that lay be his bed side
Gan forto laugh and scorned hym ful faste
No dreme quod he may myne herte agaste
That I wil let forto do my thynges
I set not a stree be dremynges
For swevenes be bot vanitees and iapes
Men dreme alway of ovles and of apes
And of many a mase ther with al
Men dreme of thynges that nevir was ne shal
Bot sith that I see that thou wilt here abide
And thus forslowthe wilfulli the tide
God woot it reweth me and have good day
And thus he toke his leve and wente his way
And er that he had half his course sailed
Not I not whi ne what myschaunce it ailed
Bot casuelli the ship bothom rent
And ship and man vnder the water went
In sight of othir shippes hym beside
That with hym sailed atte same tide
And therfore he saide ꝑper/partelot so dere
Be soche ensamples olde maiste thou lere
That no man sholde be to recheles
Of dremes for I say the douteles
That many a dreme ful sore is forto drede
Lo in the lif of seynt kenelme I rede
That was kenulphus son the noble kyng
Of martirdom how kenelme met a thyng
A litil or he was murthrid on aday
His murthir in his avision he say
His norise hym expouned everi del
His sweven and bad forto kepe hym wel
For treson bot he was seven yere olde
And therfore litil tale he hathe tolde
Of eny dreme so holi was his herte
Be god I had levir than my sherte
That ye had herde his legende as have I
Dame ꝑper/partelot I say yov trevli
Macorbouse that writith the vision
In affrike of the worthi Ciprion
Affermeth dremes and saith that ther ben
Warnyng of thynges that men aftir seen
And ferthermore I pray yow lokith wel
The olde testament of danyel
If he helde dremes bot vanite
Rede eke of Iesop and ye shal see
Whethir dremes be somtyme I say not al
Warnyng of thynges that shal aftir fal
Lo eke of Egipt the kyng dan pharao
His baker and his boteler also
Wher thei ne felt non effect in dremes
Whoso wolde seche the arte of sondri remes
May rede of dremes many a wondir thyng
Lo Cressus which that was of lide the kyng
Met he not that he sat vpon a tre
Which that signified he sholde an hanged be
Lo hir Andromaria Ecters wif
That day that Ector sholde lose his lif
She dremed on the same night beforne
How that the lif of Ector sholde be lorne
If thilk day he went into batail ¶¶nonne preest
She warned hym bot it might not availe
He wente forto feight netherles
Bot he was slayn of achilles
Bot thilke tale is al to longe to tel
And eke it is nigh day I may not dwel
Shortli I say as for conclusiou
That I shal have of this avisiou
Adversitees and I say ferthermore
That I ne tel of laxatifs no store
For thei be venymes I woot right wel
I hem defy I love hem nevir adele
Now late vs speke of myrthe and stynt al this
Madam ꝑper/partelot as have I blis
Of on thyng god hath sente me large grace
For when I see the beaute of youre face
Ye be so scarlet rede aboute youre yhen
It makith al my drede forto deyen
For also siker as in principio
Melier est hominis confucio
Madam the sentence of this latyn is
Woman is mannes ioy and blis
For when I fele anight youre soft side
Al be it that I may not on yov ride
For that oure perche is made so narow allas
I am so ful of ioy and solace
That I defi swevenes and dreme
And with that woorde he flawe doun fro the beme
For it was day and eke his hennes al
And with a chvk he gan hem forto cal
For he had founde a corne lay in the yerde
Rial he was and no more afeerd
He federed ꝑper/partelot twenti tyme
And trade hir or it were pryme
He loked as he were a grym lyou
And on his toos he romed vp and doun
Hym deyned not to set his fet his feet vpon the grounde
Ay chuked he when he had a corne y founde
And to hym than ran his wives al
Thus rial as a prince in his hal
Leve I this chauntclere in his pasture
And aftir wil I tel of his aventure
When the monyth in which the worlde began
That hight marche when ferst god made man
Was complete and passed were also
Sith marche began thritti daies and two
Befel that chauntcler in his pride
His seven wives walkyng hym beside
Caste vp his yhen to the bright son
That in the signe of taurvs was y ron
Twenti degrees and on and somwhat more
He knewe be kynde and be non othir lore
That it was pryme he crewe with ful blisful steven
The son he saide is clomben vpon heven
Fourti degrees and on and more y wys
Madam ꝑper/partelot my worldes blis
Herken how this blisful briddes syng
And se the fresh floures how thei spryng
Ful is myne herte of revel and of solace
Bot sodaynli hym befel a sorwful caas
For evere the later ende of ioy is sone a goo
And comuneli oft tyme it fallith soo
And if Arthour coude faire endite
He in acronekil might saveli write
As for a soverayn notabilite
Now everi wise man herkenith me
This stori is also trewe I vndir take
As is the boke of launcelot the blake
For women helde in ful grete reverence
Now wil I turne ayen to my sentence
A col fox ful of sleight and of iniquite
That in the grove had woned yeres thre
Be hihe ymagynacion tofore caste
The same night thorugh oute the hegges braste ¶the
Into the yerde there chauntclere the faire
Was wonte and eke his wives to repaire
And in abed of wortes stil he lay
Til it was passed vndren of the day
Waytyng his tyme on chauntclere to fal
As gladli doon thise homicides al
That in a waite lig to murthir men
A fals murthrere rowkyng in thi den
O now scariot and now genylon
Fals dissymiler o greke Symon
That brought troy al wittirli to sorew
O chauntclere o cursid be that morew
That thou in the yerde flewe fro the bemes
Thou were ful wel y warned be thi dremes
That ilke day was ꝑper/parilous to the
Bot that as god before woot mote nedes be
Aftir the opynyon of certayn clerkes
Witnes of hym that my clerke is
That in scole grete altercacion
In this mater and grete disputaciou
And hath be of an hundred thousand men
And I ne can not bolte it to the bren
As can the holi doctour Augustyn
Or boute or the bisshop braderwardeyn
Wher that that goddes wil a fore wetyng
Streyneth me nedeli forto do athyng
Nedeli clepe I symple necessite
Or elles if the choise be grauntid me
To do that same thyng or to do it nought
Thorugh that god forwoot it or it were wrought
Or of his wetyng streyneth never a dele
Bot be necessite condicionel
I wil not haue to done of soche mater
Mi tale is of a cok as ye shal here
That toke his counsail of his wif with sorew
To walken in the yerde vpon the morew
That he had met the dreme that I yow tolde
Wemens counsail be ful of coolde
Wemens counsail brought vs ferst to wo
And made Adam fro paradise to goo
There as he was ful meri and wel attese
Bot I not whom I might displease
If I counsail of women wolde blame
Passe ovir I saide it in my game
Rede auctours where thei trete of soche matere
And what thei seyen of women here
Thise be the cokkes wordes and not myne
I can no harme of no woman diuine
Faire in the son lieth merili
To bathe hir ꝑper/partelot and hir sistres by
Ayen the son and chauntclere so fre
Sange merier than the mere maiden in the see
For phisiliagus saith witterli
How that thei syng wel and merili
And so befel as he caste his yhe
Amonge the wortes vpon a botterflye
He was war of this fox that lay ful lowe
Nothyng ne luste hym than forto crowe
And cried anon cok cok and vp he sterte
As a man that was a fraied in his herte
For naturelli a beest desireth to flee
Fro his contraire if he may it see
Thogh he never had seen it erst with his yhe
This chauntcler when he gan hym aspy
He wolde have fled bot that the fox anon
Saide gentil sir allas what wil ye doon
Be ye affraied of me that am youre freende
Certes sir than be ye vnhende
If I to yow wil harme or vileny
I am not come youre counsail to espy
For trevli the cause of my comyng
Was oneli to herken how that ye syng
For treuli ye have as meri a steven
As an angil that is in heven ¶nonne preest
Therwith ye have in mesike more felyng
Than had bois or eny that can syng
Mi lorde youre fadir god his soule blis
And eke youre modir of hir gentilnes
Have in my house be to her grete ease
And certes sir right fayn wolde I yow plese
Bot for men speke of syngyng I wil sey
So mote I browke thyn yhen twey
Save ye I ne harde nevir man so syng
As did youre fadir in the mornyng
Certes it was of herte al that he songe
And forto make his voice the more stronge
He wolde so peyne hym that with bothe his yhen
He moste wynke so loude he did cryen
And stonde on his tipto ther with al
And streched forthe his nek longe and smal
And eke he was of soche discreciou
That ther nas no man in no regiou
That hym in songe or wisdom might passe
I have wel rad dan bournel ther as
A monge his vers ther was a cok
For a preestes son yaf hym a knok
Vpon his leg whiles he was yonge and nice
He made hym forto lose his benefice
Bot certes ther is no comparison
Betwixt wisdom and discresiou
Of youre fadir and of his sotilte
Now syng sir for seint charite
Late se can ye your fadir conterfete
This chauntclere his wynges gan to bete
As man that coude his treson not aspy
So was he ravished with his flatery
Allas ye lordes many a fals flaterer
Is in youre courte and many a lesynger
That plesen yow more be my faith
Than he that sothefastnes vnto yov seith
Rede ecclesiatres of flatery
Be war ye lordes of her trecheri
This chauntecler stood hihe vpon his toos
Strechyng his nek and helde his yhen cloos
And gan to crowe lowde for the nones
And dan Russel sterte vp al at ones
And be the gargage hent chauntclere
And on his bak towarde the wood hym bere
For yit was ther no man hym swed
O destyne might not be eschewed
Allas that chauntclere flewe fro the bemes
Allas his wif ne reched of his dremes
And on a friday fel al this myschaunce
O venus that arte goddesse of plesaunce
Sith that thi servant was this chauntcler
And in thi service did al his power
More for delite than the worlde to multiply
Whi woldest thou soffre on thi day to dey
O gavfrede dere maister soverayn
That when the worthi kyng Richarde was slayn
Which compleyndest his dethe ful sore
Whi ne had I now thi sentence and thi lore
The friday forto chide as did ye
For on a friday shortly slayn was he
Then wolde I shewe yow how that I cowde pleyn
For chauntcler and for his peyne
Certes soche cry ne lamentaciou
Was of ladies made when illiou
Was wonne and pirrus with his streight swerde
When he hente kyng Priam be the beerde
And slough hym as saide Enydos
As maden al the hennes in the cloos
When thei had sene of chauntclere that sight
Bot sodeynli dan ꝑper/partelot shright
Wel lovder than did hasdrvbaldas wif
When that hir husbonde had loste his lif
And that the romayns had brent Cartage ¶the
She was so ful of turment and of rage
That wilfulli into the fire she sterte
O woful hennes right so cried ye
And when that Nero brent the Cite
Of Rome cried the senatours wives
For that hir husbondes sholde lose her lyves
Withouten gilt Nero hath hem slayn
Now wil I tourne to my tale ayen
This seli widow and hir doughtres two
Herde the hennes cry and make woo
And oute atte dore sterte thei anon
And saughe the fox towarde the grove goon
And bare vpon his bak the cok awey
And cried oute harow and welawey
A . A the fox and aftir hem thei ren
And eke with stones many anothir man
Ren col oure dog talbot and gerlonde
And malkyn with hir distaf in honde
Ren cow calf and eke the veri hogges
Sore afeerde for berkyng of the dogges
And showtyng of men and of women eke
Thei ran so her herte thei thought to breke
Thei yelleden as feendes doo in hel
The dokes cried as men wolde hem quel
Oute of the hives come the swarme of bees
The gees for feerde flewh over the trees
So hidous was the noise A benedicite
Certes he iak strawe and his meyne
Ne made nevir shoutes half so shrill
When that thei wolde eny flemyng kil
As that ilk day was made vpon the fox
Of bras thei brought hornes and of box
Of horne of bone in which thei pompet
And ther with al thei shriked and shouted
It semed as at heven sholde fal
Now good I prey yow herkenith al
Lo how fortune turned sodainli
The hope and eke the pride of her envi
The Cok that lay vpon the fox bak
In al his drede vnto the fox spak
And saide sir if I were as ye
Yit sholde I say as wis god helpe me
Turne ayen ye provde cherles al
A Veri pestilence vpon yov fal
Now am I come vnto this wood side
Maugre youre hed the Cok shal here abide
I wil hym ete in feith and that anon
The fox answered in faith it shal be done
And he spak that worde al sodeynli
This cok brak fro his mouthe delyverli
And hihe vpon a tre he fleih anon
And when the fox saughe that he was goon
Allas quod he o chauntcler allas
I have quod he done to yov trespas
In asmoche as I made yow aferde
When I yov hente and brought oute of the yerde
Bot sir I did it not in no wikked entent
Cometh doun and I shal tel yow what I mente
I shal sey sothe god helpe me soo
Nay than quod he I shrew vs bothe twoo
And ferst I shrewe myself bothe blood and bones
If thou begile me ofter than ones
Thou shalte no more with thi flateri
Do me to synge and wynke with myne yhe
For he that wynkith when he sholde see
As wisseli god late hym nevir the
Nay quod the fox god yeve hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of governaunce
That iangleth when he sholde have pees
Lo soche it is forto be recheles
And necligent and trist on flateri
Bot ye that holde this tale a foly
As of a fox of a cok and of an hen
Takith the moralite good men ¶maunsiple
For seint poule seith al that wreten is
To oure doctrine it is wreten y wis
Take the frute and with the chaf be stil
Now good god if it be thi wil
As saith my lord god make vs al good men
And bryng vs al to the hihe blis Amen

l.hi:
Here endith the non preestes tale and
here begynneth the mansipales ꝓprolog

div.l: (base) And here folweth the prologe of the Manciples tale
(base) Woot ye nat where ther stant a litel town
(base) Which that clepid is Bobbe vpanddown
(base) Vnder the Blee in Caunterbury weye
(base) Ther gan oure hoost for to iape and pleye
(base) And seyde sires what Don is in the Myre
(base) Is ther no man for preyere ne for hyre
(base) That wole awake oure felawe al bihynde
(base) A theef myghte hym ful lightly robbe and bynde
(base) Se how he nappeth se how for Cokkes bones
(base) That he wol falle from his hors atones
(base) Is that a Cook of Londoun with meschaunce
(base) Do hym come forth he knoweth his penaunce
(base) For he shal telle a tale by my fey
(base) Althogh it be nat worth a botel hey
(base) Awake thow Cook quod he god yeue thee sorwe
(base) What eyleth thee to slepe by the morwe
(base) Hastow had fleen al nyght or artow dronke
(base) Or hastow with som quene al nyght yswonke
(base) So that thow mayst nat holden vp thyn heed
(base) This Cook that was ful pale and no thyng reed
(base) Seyde to oure hoost so god my soule blesse
(base) As ther is falle on me swich heuynesse
(base) Noot I nat why that me were leuere slepe
(base) Than the beste galoun wyn in Chepe
(base) Wel quod the Manciple if it may don ese
(base) To thee sir Cook and to no wight displese
(base) Which that here rideth in this compaignye
(base) And that oure hoost wole of his curteisye
(base) I wole as now excuse thee of thy tale
(base) For in good feith thy visage is ful pale
(base) Thyne eyen daswen eek as that me thynketh
(base) And wel I woot thy breth ful soure stynketh
(base) That sheweth wel thow art nat wel disposed
(base) Of me certeyn thow shalt nat ben yglosed
(base) Se how he ganeth lo this dronken wight
(base) As though he wolde swolwe vs anon right
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man by thy fader kyn
(base) The deuel of helle sette his foot ther yn
(base) Thy cursed breeth infecte wol vs alle
(base) Fy stynkynge swyn fy foule mote thee falle
(base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sire wol ye Iusten atte Fan
(base) Ther to me thynketh ye ben wel yshape
(base) I trowe that ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a straw
(base) And with his speche the Cook wax wroth and wraw
(base) And on the Manciple bigan he nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche and doun the hors hym caste
(base) Wher as he lay til that men vp hym took
(base) This was a fair chyuachee of a Cook
(base) Allas he nadde yholde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his Sadel
(base) Ther was gret showuyng bothe to and fro
(base) To lifte hym vp and muchel care and wo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple thanne spak oure hoost
(base) By cause drynke hath domynacioun
(base) Vpon this man by my sauacioun
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wolde his tale
(base) For were it wyn or old or moisty Ale
(base) That he hath dronke he speketh in his nose
(base) And fneseth faste and eek he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do moore than ynow
(base) To kepen hym and his capil out of the Slow
(base) And if he falle from his capil eft soone
(base) Than shal we alle haue ynow to doone
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) In liftynge vp his heuy dronken cors
(base) Telle on thy tale of hym make I no fors
(base) But yet Manciple in feith thow art to nyce
(base) Thus openly repreue hym of his vice
(base) Another day he wole par auenture
(base) Reclayme thee and brynge thee to lure
(base) I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
(base) As for to pynchen at thy rekenynges
(base) That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
(base) No quod the Manciple that were a gret mescheef
(base) So myghte he lightly brynge me in the snare
(base) Yet hadde I leuere payen for the Mare
(base) Which he rit on than he sholde with me stryue
(base) I wol nat wrathe hym also mote I thryue
(base) That that I spak I seyde it in my bourde
(base) And wite what I haue here in a gourde
(base) A draughte of wyn ye of a rype grape
(base) And right anon ye shul seen a good Iape
(base) This Cook shal drynke ther of if I may
(base) Vp peyne of deeth he wol nat seye me nay
(base) And certeynly to tellen as it was
(base) Of this vessel the Cook drank faste allas
(base) What neded it he drank ynow biforn
(base) And whan he hadde powped in this horn
(base) To the Manciple he took the gourde agayn
(base) And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn
(base) And thanked hym in swich wise as he kowde
(base) Thanne gan oure hoost to laughen wonder lowde
(base) And seyde I se wel it is necessarie
(base) Where that we goon good drynke we with vs carye
(base) For that wol turne rancour and disese
(base) Tacord and loue a many a wrong appese
(base) O Bacus yblessed be thy name
(base) That so kanst turnen ernest in to game
(base) Worship and thank be to thy deitee
(base) Of that matere ye gete namoore for me
(base) Telle on thy Manciple I the preye
(base) Wel sir quod he now herkneth what I seye
(base) Here endeth the prologe of the Maunciple
(base) Explicit ꝓprophemiıı̄un
(base) Here bigynneth the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Narrat
(base) Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adoun
(base) As olde bokes maken mencioun
(base) He was the mooste lusty bachiler
(base) In al this world and eek the beste Archer
(base) He slow Phitoun the serpent as he lay
(base) Slepynge agayn the sonne vpon a day
(base) And many another noble worthy dede
(base) He with his bowe wroghte as men may rede
(base) Pleyen he koude on euery Mynstralcye
(base) And syngen that it was a melodye
(base) To heren of his clere voys the soun
(base) Certes the kyng of Thebes Amphioun
(base) That with his syngyng walled that Citee
(base) Koude neuere syngen half so wel as he
(base) Ther to he was the semelieste man
(base) That is or was sith that the world bigan
(base) What nedeth it hise fetures to discryue
(base) For in this world was noon so fair on lyue
(base) He was therwith fulfild of gentillesse
(base) Of honour and of parfit worthynesse
(base) This Phebus that was flour of Bachelrye
(base) As wel in fredom as in Chiualrye
(base) For his desport in signe eek of victorie
(base) Of Phitoun so as telleth vs the storie
(base) Was wont to beren in his hand a bowe
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a Crowe
(base) Which in a Cage he fostred many a day
(base) And taughte it speke as men teche a Iay
(base) Whit was this Crowe as is a Snow whit swan
(base) And contrefete the speche of euery man
(base) He kowde whan he sholde telle a tale
(base) Ther with in al this world no nyghtyngale
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) Beter syngen þan eny nyȝtyngale
(base) Ne koude by an hondred thousand deel
(base) Syngen so wonder myrily and weel
(base) Now hadde this Phebus in his hous a wyf
(base) Which that he louede moore than his lyf
(base) And nyght and day dide euere his diligence
(base) Hire for to plese and doon hire reuerence
(base) Saue oonly that the sothe if I shal sayn
(base) Ialous he was and wolde han kept hire fayn
(base) For hym were looth byiaped for to be
(base) And so is euery wight in swich degree
(base) But al for naught for it auaileth noght
(base) A good wyf that is clene in werk and thoght
(base) Sholde nat be kept in noon awayt certayn
(base) And trewely the labour is in vayn
(base) To kepe a shrewe .for it wol nat be
(base) This holde I for a verray nycetee
(base) To spille labour for to kepe wyues
(base) Thus writen olde clerkes in hir lyues
(base) But now to purpos as I first bigan
(base) This worthy Phebus dooth al that he kan
(base) To plesen hire wenynge for swich plesaunce
(base) And for his manhode and his gouernaunce
(base) That no man sholde han put hym from hire grace
(base) But god it woot ther may no man embrace
(base) As to destreyne a thyng which that nature
(base) Hath naturelly set in a creature
(base) Take any bryd and put it in a Cage
(base) And do al thyn entente and thy corage
(base) To fostre it tendrely with mete and drynke
(base) Of alle deyntees that thow kanst bithynke
(base) And kepe it also clenly as thow may
(base) Although his Cage of gold be neuer so gay
(base) Yet hath this bryd by twenty thousand fold
(base) Leuere in a Forest that is rude and cold
(base) Gon ete wormes and swich wrecchednesse
(base) For euere this bryd wol doon his bisynesse
(base) To eschape out of his Cage if he may
(base) His libertee this bryd desireth ay
(base) Lat take a Cat and fostre hym wel with Milk
(base) And tendre flessh and make his couche of silk
(base) And lat hym seen a Mous go by the wal
(base) Anon he weyueth Milk and flessh and al
(base) And euery deyntee that is in that hous
(base) Swich appetit hath he to ete a Mous
(base) Lo heere hath lust his domynacioun
(base) And appetit flemeth discrecioun
(base) A she wolf hath also a vileyns kynde
(base) The lewedeste wolf that she may fynde
(base) And leest of reputacioun that wol she take
(base) In tyme whan hire lust to han a make
(base) Alle thise ensamples speke I by thise men
(base) That ben vntrewe but no thyng by wommen
(base) For men han euere a likerous appetit
(base) On lower thyng to parformen hir delit
(base) Than on hire wyues be they neuer so faire
(base) Ne neuer so trewe ne so debonaire
(base) Flessh is so newfangel with meschaunce
(base) That we ne konne in no thyng han plesaunce
(base) That sowneth in to vertu any while
(base) This Phebus which that thoughte vpon no gile
(base) Deceyued was for al his iolitee
(base) For vnder hym another hadde she
(base) A man of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to Phebus in comparisoun
(base) The moore harm is it happeth ofte so
(base) Of which ther cometh muchel harm and wo
(base) And so bifel whan Phebus was absent
(base) His wyf anon hath for hire lemman sent
(base) Hir lemman certes this is a knauyssh speche
(base) Foryeueth it me and that I yow biseche
(base) The wise Plato seith as ye may rede
(base) The word moot nede acorde with the dede
