div.l: (base) If men shal telle proprely a thyng
(base) The word moot cosyn be to the werkyng
(base) I am a boystous man right thus seye I
(base) Ther nys no difference trewely
(base) Bitwix a wyf that is of heigh degree
(base) If of hire body deshoneste she be
(base) And a poore wenche oother than this
(base) If it so be they werke bothe amys
(base) But that the gentile in estat aboue
(base) She shal be clepid his lady as in loue
(base) And for that oother is a poore womman
(base) She shal be clepid his wenche or his lemman
(base) And god it woot myn owene deere brother
(base) Men leyn that oon as lowe as lyth that oother
(base) Right so bitwix a titlelees tiraunt
(base) And an Outlawe or a theef erraunt
(base) The same I seye ther is no difference
(base) To Alisandre was told this sentence
(base) That for the tiraunt is of gretter myght
(base) By force of meyne for to sleen doun right
(base) And brennen hous and hoom and make al playn
(base) Lo therfore is he clepid a Capitayn
(base) And for the Outlawe hath but smal meynee
(base) And may nat doon so gret an harm as he
(base) Ne brynge a contree to so gret meschief
(base) Men clepen hym an Outlawe or a theef
(base) But for I am a man noght textuel
(base) I wol noght telle of textes neuer a del
(base) I wol go to my tale as I bigan
(base) Whan Phebus wyf hadde sent for hire lemman
(base) Anon they wroghte al hire lust volage
(base) The white Crowe that heng ay in the Cage
(base) Biheld hir werk and seyde neuer a word
(base) And when that hoom was come Phebus the lord
(base) This Crowe sang Cokkow Cokkow Cokkow
(base) What bryd quod Phebus what song syngestow
(base) Ne were thow wont so myrily to synge
(base) That to myn herte it was a reioysynge
(base) To here thy voys allas what song is this
(base) By God quod he I synge nat amys
(base) Phebus quod he for al thy worthynesse
(base) For al thy beautee and thy gentillesse
(base) For al thy song and al thy Mynstralcye
(base) For al thy waityng blered is thyn eye
(base) With oon of litel reputacioun
(base) Nat worth to thee in comparisoun
(base) The montaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
(base) For in thy bed thy wif I sey hym et cetera
(base) What wol ye moore the Crowe anon hym tolde
(base) By sadde toknes and by wordes bolde
(base) How that his wyf hadde doon hire lecherye
(base) Hym to gret shame and to gret vileynye
(base) And tolde hym ofte he say it with hise eyen
(base) This Phebus gan aweyward for to wryen
(base) And thoughte his sorweful herte brast atwo
(base) His bowe he bente and sette ther Inne a flo
(base) And in his Ire his wyf thanne hath he slayn
(base) This is theffect ther nys namoore to sayn
(base) For sorwe of which he brak his Mynstralcye
(base) Bothe harpe and Lute and Gyterne and Sawtrye
(base) And eek he brak hise arwes and his bowe
(base) And after that thus spak he to the Crowe
(base) Traytour quod he with tonge of Scorpioun
(base) Thow hast me broght to my confusioun
(base) Allas that I was wroght why nere I ded
(base) O deere wyf o gemme of lustihed
(base) That were to me so sad and eek so trewe
(base) Now lystow ded with face pale of hewe
(base) Ful giltlees that dorste I swere ywys
(base) O rakel hand to doon so foule amys
(base) O trouble wit o Ire recchelees
(base) That vnauysed smytest giltlees
(base) O wantrust ful of fals suspecioun
(base) Where was thy wit and thy discrecioun
(base) O euery man be war of rakelnesse
(base) Ne trowe ye no thyng withouten strong witnesse
(base) Smyt nat to soone er that ye witen why

div.l: (base) And beth auysed wel and sobrely
(base) Er ye do any execucioun
(base) Vpon youre Ire for suspecioun
(base) Allas a thousand folk hath rakel Ire
(base) Fully fordoon or broght hem in the Myre
(base) Allas for sorwe I wol my seluen sle
(base) And to the Crowe o false theef seyde he
(base) I wol thee quyte anon thy false tale
(base) Thow songe whilom lyk a nyghtyngale
(base) Now shaltow false theef thy song forgon
(base) And eek thy white fetheres euerichon
(base) Ne neuere in al thy lyf ne shaltow speke
(base) Thus shal men on a traytour ben awreke
(base) Thow and thyn ofspryng euere shul be blake
(base) Ne neuere swete noyse shul ye make
(base) But euere crye agayn tempest and rayn
(base) In tokenynge that thurgh thee my wyf is slayn
(base) And to the Crowe he stirte and that anon
(base) And pulled hise white fetheres euerichon
(base) And made hym blak and refte hym al his song
(base) And eek his speche and out at dore hym slong
(base) Vnto the deuel which I hym bitake
(base) And for this cas ben alle Crowes blake
(base) Lordynges by this ensample I yow preye
(base) Beth war and taketh kepe what I seye
(base) Ne telleth neuere no man in youre lyf
(base) How that another man hath dight his wyf
(base) He wol yow haten mortally certeyn
(base) Daun Salomon as wise clerkes seyn
(base) Techeth a man to kepen his tonge wel
(base) But as I seyde I nam nat textuel
(base) But nathelees thus taughte me my dame
(base) My sone thenk on the Crowe agoddes name
(base) My sone keep wel thy tonge and kepe thy freend
(base) A wikke tonge is worse than a feend
(base) My sono kepe wel þi tonge and kepe þi frende
(base) My sone from a feend men may hem blesse
(base) My sone god of his endelees goodnesse
(base) Walled a tonge with teeth and lippes eke
(base) For man sholde hym auyse what he speeke
(base) My sone ful ofte for to muche speche
(base) Hath many a man ben spilt as clerkes teche
(base) But for litel speche auysely
(base) Is no man shent to speke generally
(base) My sone thy tonge sholdestow restreyne
(base) At alle tymes but whan thow doost thy peyne
(base) To speke of god in honour and prayere
(base) The firste vertu sone if thow wolt leere
(base) Is to restreyne and kepe wel thy tonge
(base) Thus lernen children whan that they ben yonge
(base) My sone of muchel spekyng yuele auysed
(base) Ther lasse spekyng hadde ynow suffised
(base) Comth muchel harm thus was me told and taught
(base) In muchel speche synne wanteth naught
(base) Wostow wher of a rakel tonge serueth
(base) Right as a swerd forkitteth and forkerueth
(base) An arm atwo my deere sone right so
(base) A tonge kitteth frendship al atwo
(base) A Ianglere is to god abhomynable
(base) Rede Salomon so wys and honurable
(base) Rede Dauid in his psalmes rede Senekke
(base) My sone spek noght but with thyn hed thow bekke
(base) Dissimule as thow were deef if that thow heere
(base) A Ianglere speke of perilous matere
(base) The flemyng seith and lerne it if thee leste
(base) That litel Ianglyng causeth muchel reste
(base) My sone if thow no wikked word hast seyd
(base) Thee thar nat drede for to be biwreyd
(base) But he that hath mysseyd I dar wel sayn
(base) He may by no wey clepe his word agayn
(base) Thyng that is sayd is seyd and forth it gooth
(base) Though hym repente or be hym leef or looth
(base) He is his thral to whom that he hath sayd
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: (base) A tale of which he is now yuele apayd
(base) My sone be war and be noon Auctour newe
(base) Of tidynges wher they ben false or trewe
(base) Wher so thow come amonges heye or lowe
(base) Kepe wel thy tonge and thynk vpon the Crowe
(base) Here is ended the Manciples tale of the Crowe
(base) Explicit fabula mancipij

Here endith the maunciples tale and here
begynneth the persons prolog
Be that the manciple had his tale endid
The sonne fro the southe side is discendid
So lowe he was and nameli to my sight
Degrees nyne and twenti of height
hen of the clok it was so as I gesse
For elleven foot al night more or lesse
Mi shadowe as at thilke tyme as there
Of vj feet as my lengh partid were
In six foot equale of porcion
Therwith the mones exaltacion
I mene libra alwey assende
As we were entring in atte thropes ende
For with oure ooste as we were wonte to cry
As in this caas oure ioli company
Saide in this wise lordynges everichon
Now lakkith vs no tale more than oon
Fullfillid is my sentence at my degre
Who wil now tel a tale lat see
Almoost is fulfilled myne ordinance
I prey to god so gif hym right good chaunce
That tellith vs a tale lusteli
Sir preest quod he arte thou avikeri
Or arte thou aꝑper/parson say sothe be thi fay
Be what thou be the likith not our play
For everi man save thou hathe tolde his tale
Vnbokil and shewe what is in thi male
For trevli me thynkith be thi chere
Thou sholdest knyt vp wel a grete matere
Tel vs a fable anon for cokkes bones
This ꝑper/parson answered al atones
Thou gettest fable y tolde non for me
For poule wroot vnto the tymothe
Reprevyng hem that weyven sothfastnes
And / tel fables and soche wrechednes
Whi sholde I sowe draf oute of my fist
Where that I may sowe wheet if me list
For which I say if the lust to here
Moralite and vertvose matere
And than that ye wil yif me audience
I wolde fayn at Cristes reverence
Do yow plesaunce leful as I can
Bot tristith wel I am a sothren man
I can nat geest rvm ram ruf be letter
Ne god woot ryme holde I bot lewde letter
And therfore if the list I wil not glose
I wil yow tel a meri tale in prose
To knet vp al this feest and make anende
And Ihu for his grace wit me sende
To shewe yow the way in this viage
Of thilke parfite gloriouse pilgrymage
That hight Ierusalem celestial
And if ye vouchesaf anon ye shal
Begyn my tale for which I prey
Tel your ad vise I can no bettir sey
Bot netheles this meditacion
I put it as vndir corecciou
Of clerkes for I noot the text wel
Can take bot the sentence tristith wel
Therfore I make ꝓprotestacion
That I wil stonde to corecciou
Vpon this woorde we have assentid sone
For as it semed it was forto done
To ende in som vertuouse sentence
And forto yeve hym speche and audience
And bad oure ooste he sholde to hem say
That al we yeve leve to tel his tale hym to pay ¶ꝐPer/Par
Oure oost had the wordes for al vs
Sir preest quod he now faire moot yow fal
Say what yow list and we shal gladli here
And with that worde he saide in this manere
Tellith quod he youre meditacion
Bot haste yow the sonne wil doun
Bethe fructuouse and that in litil space
And to do wel god sende yow his grace
Here begynneth the ꝑper/parsons tale

div.ab: (base) Here bigynneth the Persons tale

(base) Iere 6ᵒ State super vias et videte et interrogate de semitis
antiquis que sit via bona et ambulate in ea et inuenietis refrigerium animabus vestris et cetera

(base) Ovre swete lord god of heuene that no man wole
perisse but wole that we comen alle to the kNoweliche
of hym and to the blisful lyf that is pardurable
(base) amonesteth vs by the prophete Ieromie that seith in this wise

(base) Stondeth vp on the weyes and seeth and axeth of olde pathes that is to seyn of olde sentences which is the goode
wey
(base) and walketh in that wey and ye shal fynde refresshynge for youre soules et cetera

(base) Manye been the weyes espirituels that leden folk to oure lord Ihesu crist and to the regne
of glorie

(base) of whiche weyes ther is a ful noble wey and
a ful couenable which may nat faile to man ne to womman that thurgh synne hath mysgoon fro the righte wey
of Ierusalem celestial

(base) and this wey is clepid Penitence
of which men sholde gladly herknen and enquere with al
his herte

(base) to wite what is penitence and whennes it is
clepid penitence and in how manye maneres been the accions
or werkynges of penitence

(base) and how manye spices ther
ben of penitences and whiche thynges apertenen and bihouen to penitence whiche thynges destourben penitence

(base) Seint Ambrose seith that penitence is the pleynynge of
man for the gilt that he hath doon and namoore to doon
any thyng for which hym oghte to pleyne

(base) And som dectour seith Penitence is the waymentynge of man that sorweth for his synne and pyneth hym self for he hath
mysdoon

(base) Penitence with certeyne circumstances is verray
repentance of a man that halt hym self in sorwe and oother
peyne for hise giltes

(base) and for he shal be verray penitent
he shal first biwailen the synnes that he hath doon and
stedefastly purposen in his herte to haue shrift of mouthe
and to doon satisfaccioun

(base) and neuere to doon thyng for which
hym oghte moore to biwaile or to compleyne and to continue in goode werkes or ellis his repentance may nat auayle

(base) For as seith Seint Isydre he is a Iapere and a gabbere and
no verray repentant that eft soone dooth thyng for which hym
oghte repente

(base) wepynge and nat for to stynte to do synne
may nat auaile

(base) But nathelees men shal hope that at euery
tyme that man falleth be it neuer so ofte that he may arise thurgh
penitence if he haue grace but certeynly it is greet dowithe

(base) for
as seith Seint Gregorie vnnethe ariseth he out of his synne
that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage

(base) and ther fore
repentant folk that stynte for to synne and forlete synne er that
synne forlete hem holy chirche halt hem siker of hire sauacion

(base) and he that synneth and verraily repenteth hym in his laste
holy chirche yet hopeth his sauacioun by the grete mercy of oure
lord Ihesu crist for his repentance but taak the siker wey

(base) and
Now sith that I haue declared yow what thyng is penitence
Now shul ye vnderstonde that ther been iij accions of penitence
(base) The firste is that if a man be baptised after that he hath synned

(base) Seint
Augustyn seith but he be penitent for his olde synful lyf he may
nat bigynne the newe clene lyf

(base) for certes if he be baptised with
oute penitence of his olde gilt he receyueth the mark of baptesme but nat the grace ne the remissioun of hise synnes til he haue repentance verray

(base) Another defaute is this that men doon
deedly synne after that they han receyued baptesme

(base) The
thridde defaute is that men fallen in venyal synnes after
hire baptesme fro day to day

(base) ther of seith Seint Augustyn
That penitence of goode and of humble folk is the penitence
of euery day

(base) The speces of penaunce been iij that oon of
hem is solempne Another is commune and the thridde is priuee

(base) Thilke penaunce that is solempne is in two maneres as
to be put out of holy chirche in lente for slaughtre of children
and swich manere thyng

(base) Another is whan man hath synned
openly of which synne the fame is openly spoken in the contree
and thanne holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym for to
doon open penance

(base) Commune penaunce is that preestes enioynen
men communly in certeyn cas as for to goon parauenture naked in
pilgrymage or barefoot

(base) Pryuee penaunce is thilke that men
doon al day for priuee synnes of whiche we shryue vs pryuely
and receyue pryuee penance

(base) Now shaltow vnderstande
what bihoueth and is necessarie to verray parfit penitence and
this stant on iij thynges

(base) Contricioun
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
of herte Confessioun of
Mouth and Satisfaccioun

(base) for which seith Seint Iohn Grisostomus
Penitence destreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enioyned with contricioun of herte and shrift of Mowithhe with satisfaccioun and in wirkynge of alle manere humylitee

(base) and this is
fruytful penitence agayn iij thynges in whiche we wrathe oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) this is to seyn by delit in thynkynge by recchelesnesse in spekynge by wikked synful wirkynge

(base) and agayns
thise wikkede giltes is penitence that may be likned vn to a tree

(base) The roote of this tree is contricioun that hideth hym in the herte of
hym that is verray repentant right as the roote of a tree hideth
hym in the erthe

(base) Of the roote of Contricioun spryngeth a stalke
that bereth branches and leues of confessioun and fruyt of satisfaccioun

(base) for which crist seith in his gospel dooth digne fruyt
of penitence for by this fruyt may men kNowe this tree and
nat by the roote that is hyd in the herte of man ne by the branches ne the leues of Confessioun

(base) And therfore oure Lord Ihesu crist
seith thus by the fruyt of hem shul ye kNowe hem

(base) Of this
roote eek spryngeth a Seed of grace the which Seed is moder
of Sikernesse and this Seed is egre and hoot

(base) the grace of thys
Seed spryngeth of god thurgh remembrance on the day of dome
and on the peynes of helle

(base) Of this matere seith Salomon that
in the drede of god man forleteth his synne

(base) the hete of thys
seed is the loue of god and the desirynge of the Ioye pardurable

(base) this hete draweth the herte of man to god and dooth hym hate
his synne

(base) for soothly ther is no thyng that sauoureth so wel
to a child as the mylk of his norice ne no thyng is to hym
moore abhomynable than thilke mylk whan it is medled with
oother mete

(base) right so the synful man that loueth his synne
hym semeth it is to hym moost swete of any thyng

(base) but fro that
tyme that he loueth sadly oure lord Ihesu crist and desireth the lyf
pardurable ther nys to hym no thyng moore abhomynable

(base) for soothly the lawe of god is the loue of god for which
Dauid the prophete seith I haue loued thy lawe and hated wikkednesse and hate he that loueth god kepeth his lawe and his word

(base) this tree saugh the prophete Daniel in Spirit vp on the auysion of
Nabugodonosor whanne he conseiled hym to do penitence

(base) Penance is the tree of lyf to hem that it receyuen and he that holdeth
hym in verray penitence is blessed after the Sentence of Salomon

(base) In this penitence or Contricioun man shal vnderstonde
iiij thynges that is to seyn what is Contricioun and whiche
ben the causes that moeuen a man to Contricioun and how he
sholde be contrit and what Contricioun auaileth to the soule

(base) thanne
is it thus that Contricioun is the verray sorwe that a man receyueth
in his herte for hise synnes with sad purpos to shryue hym and to
do penance and neuere moore to do synne

(base) and this sorwe shal ben
in this manere as seith Seint Bernard It shal ben heuy and
greuous and ful sharpe and poynaunt in herte

(base) first for man hath
agilt his lord and his Creatour and moore sharp and poynaunt
for he hath agilt his fader celestial

(base) and yet moore sharpe and
poynaunt for he hath wrathed and agilt hym that boughte hym
that with his precious blood hath delyuered vs fro the bondes of synne and fro the creweltee of the deuel and fro the peynes of helle

(base) The causes that oghten moeuen a man to Contricioun been vj
ffirst a man shal remembren hym of hise synnes

(base) but looke
that thilke remembrance ne be to hym no delit by no wey but gret
shame and sorwe for his gilt for Iob seith Synful men doon
werkes worthy of Confessioun

(base) And therfore seith Ezechie I
wol remembre me alle the yeris of my lyf in bitternesse of myn
herte

(base) And god seith in the Apocalipes Remembre yow fro whennes that ye ben falle for biforn that tyme that ye synned ye
were the children of god and lymes of the regne of god

(base) but
for youre synne ye ben woxe thral and foul and membres of
the feend hate of Aungeles Sclaundre of holy chirche and
foode of the false serpent perpetuel matere of the fyr of helle

(base) And yet moore foul and abhomynable for ye trespasen so ofte
tyme as dooth the hound that retorneth to ete his spewyng

(base) and
yet be ye fouler for youre longe contynuynge in synne and
youre synful vsage for which ye been roten in youre synne
as a beest in his donge

(base) swiche manere of thoughtes maken
a man haue shame of his synne and no delit as god seyth
by the prophete Ezechiel

(base) ye shal remembre yow of youre
weyes and they shullen displese yow soothly synnes been
the weyes that leden folk to helle

(base) The seconde cause that oghte
make a man to han desdeyn of synne is this that as seith
Seint Peter who so that dooth synne is thral of synne and
synne put a man in greet thraldam

(base) And therfore seith the
prophete Ezechiel I wente sorweful in desdayn of my self
Certes wel oghte a man haue desdayn of synne and with
drawe hym fro that thraldom and vileynye

(base) And lo what
seith Seneca in this matere he seith thus though I wiste
that god neither god ne
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
man ne sholde neuere kNowe it yet
wolde Ihaue desdayn for to do synne

(base) And the same Seneca also
seith Iam born to gretter thynges than to be thral to my body or than for to maken of my body a thral

(base) ne a fouler thral
may no man ne womman make of his body than for to yeue his
body to synne

(base) al were it the fouleste cherl or the fouleste womman
that lyueth and leest of value yet is he thanne moore foul and
moore in seruitute

(base) euere fro the hyer degree that man falleth the
moore is he thral and moore to god and to the world vil and abhomynable

(base) O goode god wel oghte man haue greet desdayn
of synne sith that thurgh synne ther he was fre Now is he
maked bonde

(base) And ther fore seith Seint Augustyn If thow
hast desdayn of thy seruant if he agilte or synne haue thow
thanne desdayn that thow thy self sholdest do synne

(base) take
reward of thy value that thow ne be to foul to thy self

(base) Allas wel oghten they thanne haue desdayn to ben seruantz
and thralles to synne and soore ben ashamed of hem self

(base) that god
of his endelees goodnesse hath set hem in heigh estat or yeuen hem wit strengthe of body heele beautee prosperitee

(base) and boghte hem fro the deeth with his herte blood that they so
vnkyndely agayns his gentilesse quyten hym so vileynsly
to slawghtre of hir owene soules

(base) O goode god ye wommen that been of so greet beautee remembreth yow of the
prouerbe of Salomon he seith

(base) likneth a fair womman that is
a fool of hire body lyk to a ryng of gold that were in the
groyn of a Sowe

(base) for right as a Sowe wroteth in euerich
ordure so wroteth she hire beaute in stynkynge ordure of
synne

(base) The thridde cause that oughte moeue a man to
Contricion is drede of the day of dome and of the horrible peynes of helle

(base) For as Seint Ierome seith At euery
tyme that me remembreth of the day of dome I quake

(base) for
whan I ete and drynke or what so that I do euere semeth
me that the trompe sowneth in myn ere

(base) Riseth ye vp that ben
dede and cometh to the Iugement

(base) O goode god muchel
oghte a man to drede swich a Iugement ther as we shullen ben alle as seith Seint Poul biforn the Sete of oure
lord Ihesu crist
(base) where as he shal maken a general congregacioun where as no man may ben absent

(base) for certes there
ne auaileth noon essoyne ne excusacioun

(base) and nat oonly
that oure defautes shullen be Iuged but eek that alle oure
werkes shullen openly be kNowe

(base) and as that seith Seint
Bernard ther ne shal no pletynge auaile ne no sleighte We
shullen yeue rekenynge of euerich ydel word

(base) there shul we han
a Iuge that may nat ben deceyued ne corrupt and why for
certes alle oure thoghtes ben descouered as to hym ne for prayere ne for mede he wol nat ben corrupt

(base) and therfore seith Salomon the wrathe of god ne wol nat spare no wight for prayere ne for yifte And therfore at the day of dome ther nys noon
hope to escape

(base) Wherfore as seith Seint Anselme Ful gret
anguisse shullen the synful folk haue at that tyme

(base) ther
shal the stierne and wrothe Iuge sitte aboue and vnder hym
the horrible pit of helle open to destroye hym that moot bikNowen
hise synnes whiche synnes openly ben shewed biforn god
and biforn euery creature

(base) and on the left syde mo deueles
than herte may bithynke for to harye and drawe the synful soules to the pyne of helle

(base) and with Inne the hertes of
folk shal be the bityng conscience and with oute forth shal
be the world al brennynge
(base) whider shal thanne the wrechched synful man fle to hyde hym certes he may nat hyde hym he moste come forth and shewe hym

(base) for certes as
seith Seint Ierome the erthe shal caste hym out of hym
and the See also and the Eyr also that shal ben ful of thonder clappes and lightnynges

(base) Now soothly who so wel
remembreth hym of thise thynges I gesse that his synne
shal nat torne hym in delit but to gret sorwe for drede
of the peyne of helle

(base) And therfore seith Iob to god Suffre lord that I may a while biwayle and wepe er I go with
oute returnynge to the dirke lond couered with the derknesse of deeth

(base) to the lond of mysese and of derknesse where as
is the shadwe of deeth where as ther is noon ordre or
ordinaunce but grisly drede that euere shal laste

(base) Lo here
may ye seen that Iob preyde respit a while to biwepe and
wayle his trespas for soothly o day of respit is bettre
than al the tresor of this world

(base) And for as muche as a
man may acquyte hym self biforn god by penitence in
this world and nat by tresor therfore sholde he preye to
god to yeue hym respit awhile to biwepe and biwaylen
his trespas

(base) for certes al the sorwe that a man myghte
make fro the bigynnyng of the world nys but a litel
thyng at regard of the sorwe of helle

(base) The cause why
that Iob clepeth helle the lond of derknesse

(base) vnderstondeth
that he clepeth it lond or erthe for it is stable and neuere shal faile
dirkfor he that is in helle hath defaute of light material

(base) for
certes the derke light that shal come out of the fyr that euere shal
brenne shal turne
Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
hym al to peyne that is in helle for it sheweth hym to the horrible deueles that hym tormenten

(base) couered
with the derknesse of deeth that is to seyn that he that is in helle
shal haue defaute of the sighte of god for certes the sighte of
god is the lyf pardurable

(base) The derknesse of deeth ben the synnes that the wrecched man hath doon whiche that destourben hym
to se the face of god right as a dirk clowde bitwixe vs and
the sonne

(base) Lond of myseise by cause that ther ben iij manere
of defautes agayns iij thynges that folk of this world han
in this present lyf that is to seyn honours delices and rychesses
(base) Agayns honour han they in helle shame and confusioun

(base) for wel ye woot that men clepen honour the reuerence that man
dooth to man but in helle is noon honour ne reuerence for certes
namoore reuerence shal be doon to a kyng than to a knaue

(base) for
which god seith by the prophete Ieremye thilke folk that me despisen shulle ben in despit

(base) honour is eek clepid greet lordshipe
ther shal no wight seruen oother but of harm and torment
Honour is eek clepid greet dignytee and heighnesse but in helle
shul they ben al for troden of deueles

(base) As god seith the horrible deueles shullen goon and comen vp on the heuedes of dampned folk And this is for as muche as the heyere that they were
in this present lyf the moore shulle they ben abated and defouled
in helle

(base) Agayns the richesse of this world shul they han
myseyse of pouerte and this pouerte shal be in iiij thynges

(base) In defaute of tresor of which that Dauid seith the riche folk that
embraceden and oneden al hir herte to tresor of this world shulle slepen in the slepynge of deeth and no thyng ne shal they
fynden in hire handes of al hire tresor

(base) And moore ouer the
Misayse of helle shal ben in defaute of mete and drynke

(base) for
god seith thus by Moyses they shul ben wasted with honger
and the bryddes of helle shul deuouren hem with bitter deeth
and the galle of the dragon shal ben hire drynke and the
venym of the dragon hire morsels

(base) And forther ouer hire
Miseyse shal ben in defaute of clothyng for they shullen ben
naked in body as of clothyng saue the fyr in which they
brenne and othere filthes

(base) and naked shul they ben of soule of
alle manere vertues which that is the clothyng of soule where
ben thanne the gaye robes and the softe shetes and the smale shertes

(base) Lo what seith god of hem by the prophete Ysaye that vnder hem
shul ben strawed Mothathes and hire couertures shullen ben of
wormes of helle

(base) And forther ouer hire myseyse shal ben
in defaute of frendes for he is nat pouere that hath goode frendes but there is no freend

(base) for neither god ne no creature shal
ben freend to hem and euerich of hem shal haten oother with
deedly hate

(base) the sones and the doghtren shullen rebellen agayns
fader and moder and kynrede agayns kynrede and chiden and
despisen euerich of hem oother bothe day and nyght as god
seith by the prophete Michias

(base) And the louynge children that whilom loueden so flesshly euerich oother wolden euerich of hem
eten oother if they myghte

(base) for how sholde they louen hem to-
gidre in the peyne of helle whan they hateden euerich of
hem oother in the prosperitee of this lyf

(base) for truste wel hire
flesshly loue was dedly hate as seith the prophete Dauid
who so that loueth wikkednesse he hateth his soule

(base) and who
so hateth his owene soule certes he may loue noon oother
wight in no manere

(base) and therfore in helle is no solas ne
no frendshipe but euere the moore flesshly kynredes that ben
in helle the moore cursynges the moore chidynges and the
moore dedly hate ther is among hem

(base) And forther ouer
they shul haue defaute of alle manere delices for certes
delices ben after the appetites of the v wittes as Sighte
Herynge Smellynge Sauorynge and touchynge

(base) but
in helle hire sighte shal be ful of dirknesse and of smoke
and therfore ful of teerys and hire herynge ful of waymentynge and of gryntynge of teeth as seith Ihesu crist

(base) hire
nosethirles shul ben ful of stynkynge stynk And as
seith Ysaye the prophete hire sauorynge shal be ful of bitter galle

(base) and touchynge of al hir body ycouered with fyr
that neuere shal quenche and with wormes that neuere shul dyen as god seith by the mowithh of Ysaye

(base) And for as muche as they shul nat wene that they may dyen for peyne
and by hire deeth fle fro peyne that may they vnderstonde
